dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river Thames at daybreak, street-lamps reflected in t water. TILT UP to reveal the London Embankment, Big Ben i the background. Jack, an eternally optimistic lamplighter, climbs a ladde that leans against a lamppost, silhouetted against the da He dims the light and slides down to the ground. “LOVELY LONDON SKY"

dialogues.speaker: UNDERNEATH THE LOVELY LONDON SKY
dialogues.text: Jack folds his ladder and fastens it to the back of his bicycle. He climbs on and rides off. EXT. THE DOCKS NEAR THE EMBANKMENT —- CONTINUOUS Dropping down from the rooftops of London, we discover workers unloading crates and barrels of fresh produce on docks. Jack slaloms through it all as he continues on his way.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIGHT SHINES THROUGH
dialogues.text: Jack stops at a lamppost and dims the lamp. Ahead, NEEDY LONDONERS stand on a soup kitchen queue that snakes aroun the corner. VOLUNTEERS hand out food to them.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERNEATH THE LOVELY LONDON SKY
dialogues.text: Jack grabs an apple as he swerves past a fruit cart and tosses it to a MAN ON THE QUEUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack rides along the embankment, the bridge at his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack rides down an alley adjacent to a pub, three STRE URCHINS chase behind him. An urchin helps him to shut off a street-lamp.

dialogues.speaker: I KNOW...
dialogues.text: A PUB LANDLORD sweeps the footpath.

dialogues.speaker: PUB LANDLORD
dialogues.text: Oi, get out of it! The urchins run off down the alley, as Jack rides down th street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack passes St. Paul’s. A few HOMELESS PEOPLE sleep on th cathedral steps.

dialogues.speaker: LONDON SKY
dialogues.text: He rides through a flock of pigeons, scattering them, and taking us up past the dome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Jack’s wheels as he winds his way through the pa As he rides along the path, he nods to a gruff PARK KEEPE spearing rubbish into a bag, who gives him a dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack whistles as he rides onto Cherry Tree Lane, a street lined with 19th-Century homes. He passes the neighboring MILKMAN, giving him a wave.

dialogues.speaker: MILKMAN
dialogues.text: Mornin’, Jack! Jack glances up to a rooftop that has been fitted to look like the deck of a ship - at the moment, though, no one i the helm. He looks up, worried. Finally, the rooftop door creaks open and ADMIRAL BOOM appears, pushed in a wheelchair by his First Mate, BINNAC

dialogues.speaker: BINNACLE
dialogues.text: (Blows whistle: ) Admiral... above decks! Jack smiles, saluting the sailors.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: LISTEN... SOON THIS SLUMP’LL

dialogues.speaker: DISAPPEAR
dialogues.text: IT WON’T BE LONG SOONER THAN ‘YA THINK YOU’LL HEAR

dialogues.speaker: SOME BRIGHT NEW SONG
dialogues.text: He sets up his ladder at the lamppost that stands before Cherry Tree Lane - a modest house which has fallen slight into disrepair. A BOY AND GIRL appear at the window in the upper floor of Banks home, waving. JACK (cont'd) Y’awright, children? Jack waves to the children. They wave back and exit. Jack climbs the ladder. JACK (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: LOVELY LONDON SKY...
dialogues.text: Jack dims the light and glances up into the sky. He slide down the ladder, climbs onto his bicycle and rides off. BIG BEN TOLLS eight o’clock in the distance. A black car pulls up as Jack rides off. Two men in suits get out of the car: GOODING and FRYE. T men set their watches by the toll of the bell, then walk the path to the house. UP ABOVE, the Admiral and Binnacle have just made it acro the rooftop. The Admiral is outraged.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: Great steaming clams - they’ve done it again! Those blundering blowfish have rung Big Ben too soon!

dialogues.speaker: BINNACLE
dialogues.text: Storm clouds on the horizon, Sir. Heading straight for Cherry Tree Lane.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: Batten down the hatches, Mr. Binnacle. Rough seas ahead, I fear. Both men react as a SCREAM comes from the Bank’s househol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the Banks family home, the house shows some signs wear and inattention.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (The scream continues: )

dialogues.speaker: AAAHHH
dialogues.text: The door that leads into the kitchen flies open - water c be seen spraying the room. ELLEN, the housekeeper, runs i the hall in a panic and calls upstairs. ELLEN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: JANE and MICHAEL BANKS rush in from the parlor behind Ell

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What is it, Ellen?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: The bloomin’ sink’s exploded!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Not again!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Oh dear.  Michael rushes into the kitchen. The boy and girl we saw earlier, ANNABEL and JOHN, run down the steps. AUNT JANE (cont'd) Oh - Annabel, John - !

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: We heard, Aunt Jane - I'll ring the plumbers!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’ll turn off the water at the mains! John runs down into the cellar.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (Going into the kitchen: ) Thank you, darlings - Ellen, fetch us a mop and towels, will you?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (Grumbling to herself:) I told ‘im to get them pipes fixed. They been there since the Romans ruled. Ellen disappears into the cellar. GEORGIE comes down the stairs, carrying his stuffed giraffe, “Gillie.”

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: What’s happening?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Don’t go in the kitchen, Georgie - not without your Wellies -— (On phone: ) Yes, hello. We’ve had a burst pipe. (There is a TAPPING at the front door. On phone:) Excuse me — (Calling: ) Ellen, could you please get the door? I’ve got the plumbers here. Ellen comes out of the cellar with the mop and towels.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: That was quick work, wasn’t it? Hands full, she gives the towels to Georgie. ELLEN (cont'd) Here Georgie - take these. (Heading to the door:) Alright, alright - I’m coming. Gooding and Frye stand outside, tacking up a notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Good morning, mum.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: They don’t look like plumbers.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Looks over.) I meant on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: We are not plumbers - we’re lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Lawyers? Here’s me, hopin’ you'd prove useful. She absentmindedly hands the mop to Gooding and shuts the Aunt Jane her dress She wraps

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Water’s off!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (hanging up) And the plumbers are on their way. comes out of the kitchen, her hair and the front of drenched with water.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Well done, everyone. Phew! Such excitement!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Aunt Jane?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (She takes a towel from Georgie to dry off:) We’re handing out breakfasts at the union hall. I snuck away for morning hugs. Come here. the towel around Georgie and gives the three children a hug. Aunt Jane takes the towels and heads back into the kitche Georgie picks up a towel she has accidentally dropped, following her into the kitchen. There’s a knock at the door. Ellen goes over and opens it

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Will you stop that bangin’? It’s barely eight o’clock on a Sunday mornin’! (more)  ELLEN (cont'd) (She sees her mop, grabs it:) Wot’cher doin’ with my mop?

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: Forgive the intrusion, mum. Our current workload prevents us taking weekends off.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: We would like to have a word with Mr. Banks, if he is available. Ellen finally sees the notice on the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: “Notice of... Repossession?” Frye, by far the more sympathetic of the two, sighs loudl and nods sadly, looking genuinely pained. Ellen glares. ELLEN (cont'd) Wait there. She goes back inside. John and Annabel quickly turn away, pretending not to be paying attention. The lawyers peer through the door as Michael re-enters from the kitchen, thoroughly soaked, followed by Georgie. As Michael takes his jacket:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I'll be cleaning up that mess all morning.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Reaching for the jacket:) Here. Let me take that, father.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, darling. Annabel runs upstairs with the jacket.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (Undisguised contempt: ) “Scuse me, sir - the wolves are at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What do they want?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: A good thrashin’, if you ask me. (She looks into the kitchen, sighs.) Looks like the River Thames in there.  Aunt Jane comes out as Michael takes the mop from Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Don’t worry - I’ll clean up, Ellen. Why don’t you see to breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Suppose someone ‘as to - ‘less we all want to starve. She goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (Aside, to Michael: ) Why don’t you let Ellen clean up?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (A resigned sigh:) I'm afraid lately that means more work for me. The other day I found a butcher’s sack hanging on the coat rack - and my hat was in the larder. Aunt Jane catches sight of her damp hair in the hall mirr

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: I need a brush - I look a fright. (As she goes upstairs: ) Don’t forget you have guests at the door, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Right - (He goes to the door, dodging the children) I'm sorry. We're struggling through a bit of chaos this morning - They take a step into the hallway. Michael closes the doo behind them.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: So it seems. Unfortunately, Mr. Banks, our business cannot wait. Ellen reappears from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir - how exactly am I supposed to make breakfast when there’s nothing in the larder but pickled herring and marmalade?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Hand to forehead: ) The groceries - I meant to go yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (She nods, turns to go.) Very well, then. Pickled herring for breakfast, marmalade for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Once Ellen has gone:) That little shop across the park will be open. The three of us can go.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, John.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (Aside, to Annabel: ) But you said we would go to the park today!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: We'll cut through the park on the way.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: But -

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Enough, Georgie. Come along. John takes the mop from Michael.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I'll take that, Father.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Aunt Jane comes back downstairs as the twins lead Georgie into the kitchen. Michael gestures for the lawyers to joi him in the parlor. Aunt Jane follows, putting on her coat MICHAEL (cont'd) Please, come through -

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Now, what is it I can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: I am Hamilton Gooding; this is Mr. Templeton Frye. We are solicitors with the law firm of Gordy, Cordry, Gooding and Frye. Aunt Jane suppresses a laugh.  10 GOODING (cont'd) What?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Gooding notices the poster sticking out of Aunt Jane’s notebook.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: SPRUCE? Is that your garden club?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: No, it’s the “Society for the Protection of the Rights of the Underpaid Citizens of England.”

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: A labour organizer? (Archly polite, to Frye:) She's a labour organizer. Gooding and Frye sit on the sofa. Michael sits in the armchair opposite. Aunt Jane moves round, tying her belt.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Well, yes - we also run soup kitchens - it’s a never-ending job these days.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: I’m sure it is, Mrs. Banks.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Miss Banks, actually. I’m Michael’s sister.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: My wife passed away this last year.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: That’s awful! Those poor children.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Our deepest condolences.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Forgive me - what brings the two of you here this morning?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: I’m going to say my good-byes. Aunt Jane kisses Michael on the cheek and heads out.  11

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Mr. Banks, you took out a loan with Fidelity Fiduciary Bank last year against the value of your home. Aunt Jane stops and steps back to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: You did what? Michael!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I had to, Jane. I didn’t have much choice, what with Kate and the bills piling up -

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: Hard enough these days, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Yes, well, it seems you’ve fallen three months behind in payments -

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I am sorry. Kate, my wife, used to handle all our finances, you see, and I’ve been a bit off my stride. (Stands, walks to desk:) How much is it I owe you exactly?

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, the bank is now demanding you pay back the entire loan in full.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: The entire loan?

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Yes - it’s all in the contract.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: That’s more than I make in a year. I couldn’t possibly.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: Oh dear! Gooding stands to leave, picking up his hat and briefcase

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: You have five days. If you are unable to pay in full by Friday at midnight, I’m afraid we will have to repossess your home, and you will have to vacate the premises. Frye sighs, distraught. Gooding glances over, irritated.  12

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: But I work at Fidelity Fiduciary!

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Not as an accountant, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No, as a teller - I took a part- time position there this past year. You see, I’m really an artist -

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Be that as it may -

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: But my father, George Banks, was a senior partner there!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (A realization: ) Father left us bank shares! You could use them to pay off the loan.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I was saving those for the children, but - Frye stands.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: Shares? In the bank? (Brightly, to Gooding: ) That does change things, doesn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Do you have the share certificate?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Sorry? The what?

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: The document —

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: The document proving you own shares in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: ... I suppose it must be somewhere among father’s old papers. EXT. THE ADMIRAL’S ROOFTOP - CONTINUOUS On the rooftop next door, the Admiral and Binnacle are finally prepared to fire off the 8 a.m. cannon.  13

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: Primed and ready, Mr. Binnacle?

dialogues.speaker: BINNACLE
dialogues.text: Ready and charged, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: On my mark. Three, two, one - FIRE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, the cannon fire rattles the walls, knocking everything askew and terrifying the lawyers. A clock and urn land in Gooding’s hands. Ash flies out of the firepla

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Good heavens! Are you housing anarchists? Michael and Aunt Jane behave as though this is perfectly normal; they begin pushing all the furniture and belongin back into place as they speak.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: No, that’s the Admiral. He fires off a cannon to mark the hour.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: (He checks his watch:) But he’s over five minutes late.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m afraid he’s been running a little behind these last few years. Michael and Aunt Jane push the piano back in place.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: As are we, this morning. You’ve been given notice; (Hands Michael the notice) We'll see ourselves out. Come along, Mr. Frye.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: (putting on his hat) I hope you find that share certificate. I really do.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Good day to you both. (As they leave, to Frye:) You really have chosen the wrong profession, you know... The door shuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me you had taken out a loan, Michael? Michael moves away from Jane.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to worry you - or the children. I kept thinking I would catch up. Kate always managed. (He shakes his head:) Of all the thick-headed mistakes... I can’t lose our home, Jane. She’s everywhere here.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Well then we aren’t going to let that happen. But, Michael, you know we neither of us have enough money between us - so we just have to find that share certificate. Do you have any idea where father might have kept it?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Up in the attic, I suppose... (He tucks away his emotions, smiles.) «+. I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to bring you into all this.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (Exasperated: ) Michael! This is our family home, and you're about to lose it - so stop pretending everything’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are we going to lose our home? 14 Michael and Aunt Jane turn. Georgie and the twins, having entered from the dining room in their coats and wellies, been listening to them.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh, no - no, of course not, Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: I was saying you won’t have to worry, because your father owns shares in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: But you said we don’t have enough money. Michael grabs paper and pen and sketches something.  15

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well, I can make more - I ama banker now, aren’t I? That’s what bankers do - make money.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: But you’re not a banker - you’re a painter.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes, well - painters don’t make money. Not these days. Here, you see? The day has hardly begun and I’ve already made you 10 pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael hands Georgie what he’s drawn - a decent likeness a 10-pound note. Annabel and John exchange a glance, seei through Michael's false cheer instantly. Georgie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Looking at his watch:) We'd best be going.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Let’s get your hats on then. Annabel goes to the front hall coat rack to get their hat

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (With a wink, handing a few coins to John:) John, one moment. Georgie shouldn't have to spend his 10 pounds on the shopping - here you are.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Thank you, father.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (Entering: ) Off to the park now, I see.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Yes - that’s right, Ellen. Ellen helps the children with their hats. Aunt Jane takes her coat as she heads for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (To Michael: ) Shall we search the attic, then?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Don’t you have to go to work?  16

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (Rolling up her sleeves: ) Work can wait. Michael follows her up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jane - yes, I’1l1 look in the attic. Why don’t you check father’s old wardrobe? Ellen follows the children to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We’ll make lunch when we get home, Ellen. Annabel takes Gillie from Georgie, handing it to Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Gillie stays here.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (As the children leave: ) Blimey - such little grown-ups you've become.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annabel reads over the shopping list as the children walk through the park.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Father didn’t give us enough, did he?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Not nearly.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: We can ask for day-old bread at half off; that’s what mother used to do. Georgie smiles, seeing MISS LARK, the children’s wealthy neighbor, walking her dog WILLOUGHBY.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Hello, Willoughby! Hello, Miss Lark!

dialogues.speaker: MISS LARK
dialogues.text: Hello, Georgie! Twins.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Come on Georgie, we haven't got time for this.  17 Willoughby barks. Georgie notices a woman selling balloon (BALLOON LADY) in the distance. He cuts across the grass toward her:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: The balloon lady! Can we get balloons?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: No, Georgie - we haven’t enough for groceries as it is. The Park Keeper appears, calling to Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: PARK KEEPER
dialogues.text: Oi, Georgie Banks - keep off the grass! I don’t spend all day caring for it just to see my work get trampled on! Go on, hop it! Georgie sighs and reluctantly returns to the path.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Quietly, to Annabel: What if Father does lose the house?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: We'll just have to figure out a way to get it back, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You're right... That’s what mother would do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attic is a complete mess. Michael’s easels, canvases art supplies are all piled up in a corner. Michael goes o to an old desk. He searches through its drawers, then pic up a wooden storage crate. Inside the crate, Michael finds a jewelry box with an engraved “K” on its lid. When he opens it, a gentle melod plays. He takes out a necklace of his wife’s, gazing at i moment. He sets the box aside and continues searching the attic, still holding the necklace - but he can’t get the gentle melody out of his head... “A CONVERSATION"

dialogues.speaker: TODAY SEEMS EVERYTHING'S GONE WRONG HERE
dialogues.text: (more)  18 MICHAEL (cont'd) I’M LOOKING FOR THE WAY THINGS WERE I KNOW YOU’D LAUGH AND CALL ME TRAGIC

dialogues.speaker: AND I COULD SURELY USE A FEW SUGGESTIONS
dialogues.text: ON HOW TO BRUSH OUR DAUGHTER’S HAIR

dialogues.speaker: IT'S SILENT SINCE YOU WENT AWAY
dialogues.text: Michael looks out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: BUT THE CHERRY TREES FORGOT TO BLOOM
dialogues.text: He reminds himself to keep searching. The certificate... The certificate...

dialogues.speaker: MY QUESTION, KATE, IS "WHERE'D YOU GO
dialogues.text: As Aunt Jane enters, Michael puts away the necklace and closes the lid of the jewelry box, turning away to hide h emotions.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Nothing in the wardrobe. (Gazing around the attic:) Oh my goodness.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (He turns back, smiling: ) Yes, it’s quite a mess, isn’t it? Aunt Jane notices Michael's art supplies.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: What are all your art things doing up here?  19

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I wasn’t using them anymore. I should probably get rid of it all.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Have you looked in father’s old desk?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (pulling out an old snowglobe) I honestly don’t know why we kept most of this stuff to begin with. He reaches into a nearby box and pulls out an old, patche kite with a suffragette banner for a tail. MICHAEL (cont'd) I mean, why on Earth did we save this old broken thing?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Don’t you remember that kite? We used to love flying that with mother and father.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well, it won't fly anymore. Out it goes - no looking back. Michael throws the beaten kite into the rubbish box and carries it to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael carries the trash bin out to leave by the side of house, then goes back inside. A beat, and then the wind stirs. The kite shudders and lifts into the air, blown ou the trash bin. It skitters across the lane, past Jack, who is riding his bicycle. He stops in his tracks, watching the kite skip b The behavior of this kite strikes him as unusual, to say least. He glances up, sensing something in the air.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Singing softly:)

dialogues.speaker: AND MAYBE SOON FROM UP ABOVE...
dialogues.text: He pedals off in pursuit. EXT. THE PARK —- CONTINUOUS In the park, Willoughby the dog sees the kite tumble past barks madly.  20 The kite swings up to hit a MAN ON A PARK BENCH in the ba of the head, knocking off his bowler hat. Barely reacting the man calmly sets his hat back in place and continues reading a newspaper. Up ahead, the twins are poring over their errand list; Georgie, lagging behind, sees the kite tumble past - he chases after it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: How long do you think it will take us today?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, let’s see. It’s a nine minute walk to the shop. If it takes about ten minutes to purchase each item, we should be back home by- Jack races past John and Annabel on his bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ‘Scuse me, children - coming through!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Georgie! Come back!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Georgie! The twins start after Georgie, but the Park Keeper sees t

dialogues.speaker: PARK KEEPER
dialogues.text: You two - off the grass!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But our brother -

dialogues.speaker: PARK KEEPER
dialogues.text: You heard me - now! A gust of wind sends the kite over a hedge. Georgie scram through the hedge into a CLEARING, getting his clothes covered in mud. The kite is there, leaning against a ston bridge as though waiting for him. Georgie runs to it, pul out the spool of string that’s been tucked in its frame a raises the kite into the air. Clouds gather and roil. The wind grows violent, dragging Georgie off his feet as the shoots up through the clouds. John and Annabel are rushing along the path when they hea

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Help! The twins charge out across the grass and dive under the hedge.  21

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: WE’RE COMING GEORGIE! Jack, meanwhile, stops his bike on the nearby path and hurries over to rescue Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hold on...! Jack grabs hold of Georgie, pulls him down. They both pul the kite string with all their might. The sky begins to c the clouds part, and a figure, holding onto the kite’s ta comes into view... It is MARY POPPINS! Dressed in a long coat, scarf, and eccentric hat, Mary Poppins carries a carpetbag in her free hand and has a pa headed umbrella tucked under her arm. JACK (cont'd) As I live and breathe... The twins scramble through the bushes just in time to see Mary Poppins glide the last five or so feet to the ground The moment Mary Poppins lands, she addresses Georgie. Jac reels in the kite string. Brusquely:

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: You need to be more careful when the wind rises, Georgie - you nearly lost your kite. (As the twins approach: ) And you two nearly lost your Georgie. He might have got away completely had I’d not been holding on to the other end of that string. She brushes herself off, taking note of the children’s appearances. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) My goodness, Annabel - what have you done to your clothes? You could grow a garden in that much soil. And John, you're just as filthy.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: How do you know our names?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Beaming: ) Because she’s Mary Poppins, of course! And may I say you look lovely, as always.  22

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: You really think so? It is nice to see you, Jack -

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Good to see you too, Mary Poppins. (To the children: ) I was just your age when we first met, working for a chimney sweep. Jack hands the kite back to Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: How is dear old Bert?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Traveling the world he is, off to points unknown.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Well, now I am off to speak with the father of these children - this family is clearly in desperate need of a nanny. (To the children: ) Now, quick march and best foot forward, and I’ll thank you not to dawdle. Mary Poppins marches off, Georgie at her side. The twins exchange a puzzled glance.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Go on. The twins then hurry after their brother. Jack follows be and picks up his bike off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie charges into the hall, and shouts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Father! Aunt Jane - come quick! Michael rushes to the top of the steps. Georgie stands at base of the stairs holding the weatherbeaten kite, excite

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What is it, Georgie?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Has something happened?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I was flying a kite and it got caught on a nanny!  23 Michael and Aunt Jane come downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Whatever are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Come look!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Wait - where did you get that kite?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I found it in the park. (Pointing to the door:) She kept it from blowing away. They look toward the front door as Mary Poppins steps int the house for the first time in decades. Michael is so ta aback that he drops the papers he holds.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Mary... ?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: -+. Poppins?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Close your mouth please, Michael. We are still not a codfish. Aunt Jane giggles. Mary Poppins gives her a sidelong glan MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Jane Banks - still rather inclined to giggle I see. This stops Aunt Jane. Michael beams. Annabel and John run closing the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: -+. Good heavens, it really is you! You seem hardly to have aged at all.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Really! How rude. One never discusses a woman’s age, Michael. I would have hoped I had taught you better.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I didn’t mean -

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: You came back! I thought we’d never see you again.  24

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It is wonderful to see you -

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (Admiring herself in the mirror: ) Yes, it is, isn’t it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: You know her then? As Mary Poppins crosses away from the mirror, her reflect remains behind, watching her go.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Mary Poppins used to be our nanny.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: What brings you here after all this time?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: The same thing that brought me the first time: I’ve come to look after the Banks children. The twins exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Us?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (Turning: ) .«.. Oh, yes - you too.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (A little huffy: ) But we don’t need a nanny. Mother taught us to look after ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: You did just misplace Georgie, I might point out.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Only slightly. We got him back.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: We can do anything a nanny can.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins flew here on a kite. You can’t do that, can you?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What are you talking about, Georgie? Don’t be silly.  25

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, let him believe what he likes. (To Georgie: ) When your father and I were young, we used to imagine Mary Poppins could do all sorts of impossible things. Georgie alone notices the parrot on the handle of Mary Poppins’ umbrella coming to life.

dialogues.speaker: PARROT UMBRELLA
dialogues.text: (Squawking: ) Actually - Mary Poppins calmly pinches the parrot’s beak shut.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: ‘Actually,’ what?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Actually, I’d like to get back to the matter of my employment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Your umbrella talks!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Georgie, please - we're in the midst of a grown-up conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Why don’t we go upstairs, Georgie?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: But it did talk! I promise - The twins lead Georgie upstairs. Once they’ve gone:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I'm afraid sometimes Georgie suffers from an excess of imagination.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: As I recall, you had the same affliction yourself when you were young.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Did I, really? Well, those days are long behind me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Are they, indeed? (She nods, confirming something to herself.) About my employment, then -  26

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes, about that - the truth is, I simply can’t afford -

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: We can settle on terms later, although I will want my old room back, as long as it’s not a complete disaster, and I insist on having every second Tuesday off.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: But I’m afraid -

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Of course, Mary Poppins. Michael shoots Aunt Jane a look.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Good, good. That’s all settled. Then I’1l stay. Now, if you'll excuse me, the children have turned themselves into dustbins; my first order of business is to see them properly bathed and dressed. Michael pulls Aunt Jane into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Have you gone completely mad, Jane? I can’t afford to take on anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins isn’t just anyone. Don’t you see, Michael? No one’s hiring nannies anymore. The poor woman has no place to go.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Neither will we by the end of the week.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t be so grumpy. You sound just like father.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I do not!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Give Mary Poppins a chance. You need help just as much as she does.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh... very well. She can stay for the time being, I suppose. (more)  27 MICHAEL (cont'd) (Ironically: ) After all, she did fly all this way on a kite. They share a laugh. Aunt Jane smiles, hesitates. Behind them, Mary Poppins hops on the bannister and glide the stairs, leaving her bag and umbrella behind.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Those things, when we were young - they didn’t really...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (With a smile:) Happen? No...

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: No, of course not.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Ridiculous. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins glides up the bannister past Ellen, carrying armful of fresh towels.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Oh hello, Mary Poppins.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Hello, Ellen. Mary Poppins hops off the bannister. Georgie is waiting f her. His jaw drops as the parrot umbrella and her carpetb float down from above and into her hands.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: How did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: And why didn’t father believe you flew here on a kite?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Because it’s complete nonsense, of course.

dialogues.speaker: PARROT UMBRELLA
dialogues.text: (Squawking: ) Grown-ups forget. They always do.  28

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (A sharp look: ) That will be quite enough of that. I should have left you in the umbrella stand.

dialogues.speaker: PARROT UMBRELLA
dialogues.text: (Aghast: ) Not with the canes! Mary Poppins marches into the nursery, Georgie behind her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Annabel are huddled together, talking in hushed tones, when Mary Poppins arrives.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: What are you two whispering about?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN AND ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Coming to attention: ) Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (removing her hat) “Nothing” is such a useful word, isn’t it? It can mean anything and everything.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: It’s just that -

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: - you don’t require the services of a nanny.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, we have grown up a good deal in the past year, after all.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. We’ll have to see what can be done about that. Mary Poppins straightens the items on the fireplace. She reaches to adjust a china bowl on the mantelpiece.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: That was our mother’s - be careful.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (Haughtily: ) I am always careful. Mary Poppins unties her jacket belt.  29

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Anxious: ) So... you’re staying?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (removing her jacket belt) Yes, I’1l stay... until the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Looking to the nursery door.) That door is always opening. Mary Poppins unbuttons and removes her coat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Not that door - another one. Mary Poppins opens the cupboard doors and takes out some clothes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (Incredulous: ) The bathroom door?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: That’s just silly, Georgie. (To Mary Poppins, uncertain: ) Not the bathroom door?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (As she heads off:) No. But a bath would prove useful. Come along - time for a good, clean start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steam clouds fill the air. Georgie and the twins stand in their 1930's-style long underwear, watching as Mary Poppi draws a bath. The twins aren’t in the least happy about i

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Our mother always had us take our baths in the evening.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: In my experience, the perfect time of day to have a bath is when one needs a wash. Georgie will go first.  30 Mary Poppins gathers towels and washcloths, shampoo and a fresh bar of soap, which she places beside the tub.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We are perfectly capable of drawing our own baths.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: How very helpful John. In that case, you may turn off the tap. (He reaches to do so.) But not quite yet - we still have to put in the bubbles.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But I don’t like soap bubbles. Mary Poppins goes off to retrieve her bag.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then you shall have to try to avoid them at all costs.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Quietly, to Annabel: She's a tough nut, isn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Aloud: ) Alright then, but we’ll have to get this done quickly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Right, we still have to get to the grocers - and it looks as though it might rain.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I know who you should ask.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Her umbrella can’t talk, Georgie. Mary Poppins returns with her carpetbag, shaking her head

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: The very idea.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: How do you know it can’t?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Because it can’t. The very notion is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Exactly right, Annabel. It’s nonsense. Foolishness.  31

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It makes no sense. And if it makes no sense it can’t be true. Mary Poppins pulls a bottle of soa uu. es from her bag. ‘Yy ppi pull b 1 £ p bubbl £ he bag “CAN YOU IMAGINE THAT?"

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, YOU'RE RIGHT
dialogues.text: IT’S GOOD TO KNOW YOU'RE BRIGHT

dialogues.speaker: AND ANNABEL AGREES
dialogues.text: MOST FOLDEROL’S AN OPTICAL ILLUSION... YOU THREE KNOW IT’S TRUE

dialogues.speaker: I SUSPECT
dialogues.text: (AND I’M NEVER INCORRECT) THAT YOU’RE FAR TOO OLD TO GIVE IN TO IMAGINATION... As she pours the soap bubbles into the bath, a dolphin pe it's head up out of the water, much to the children’s amazement. To the dolphin: Not yet. Mary Poppins gently pushes the dolphin back underwater.

dialogues.speaker: CAN YOU IMAGINE THAT
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins reaches into her bag to pull out a pail and shovel and a rubber duck. The children watch, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: AND SEND IT DOWN THE DRAIN
dialogues.text: As Mary Poppins drops each item into the tub, they seem t magically drawn into the water, as though rocketing down slide.

dialogues.speaker: AND GIGGLE THROUGH THE DAY
dialogues.text: THEY THINK THE WORLD’S A BRAND NEW SHINY TOY She pulls a toy pirate ship out of her bag, puts it into tub and it disappears; then she sprinkles a handful of co into the water.  32 MARY POPPINS (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: THEY FALL AND GO KERSPLAT
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins searches in her bag for something, snapping fingers when she suddenly remembers where it is. She marc over and pulls a large beach umbrella out of the sink wit flourish, then slides it into the tub as well. ALTHOUGH THEY’RE DOWN AND BENT IN HALF

dialogues.speaker: CAN YOU IMAGINE THAT
dialogues.text: On second thoughts, perhaps you’re right. It makes no sense to have a bath this early -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I want to take a bath!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (Mildly surprised: ) Oh, really? Very well, then... Up you go... and in you go! She sets Georgie on the edge of the tub. He throws up his arms and slides in - he too is magically drawn into the water.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Georgie! John lunges forward, grabbing Georgie’s hand at the last possible moment - getting pulled into the water as well.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: John! Annabel sweeps away soap bubbles and peers into the water Georgie and John are nowhere to be seen. ANNABEL (cont'd) What happened? Will they be alright?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: It is just a bath, after all. But then again, it’s not my tub.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t you go after them?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: I had my bath this morning, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Well, if you won’t, I will!  33 Annabel climbs onto the back of the tub and slides in. Mary Poppins sits on the edge of the tub herself, and sli in backwards -

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Off we go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie, the twins and Mary Poppins plummet past, all of tumbling down into a magical ocean. The toys Mary Poppins in the water have all grown to enormous size. The rubber is the size of a bus; the pail and shovel are enormous.

dialogues.speaker: CAN YOU IMAGINE THAT
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins and the children float past increasingly sur scenes peopled by those they know from Cherry Tree Lane. Lark passes by with her dog Willoughby on a leash, the do towing her as he paddles through the water.

dialogues.speaker: MIGHT SEEM REAL
dialogues.text: BUT WE KNOW IT’S NOT SO! The toy pirate ship has become a full-size shipwreck. Ell can be seen through a hole in the ship’s hull, trying to the clams and minnows in her cooking pot from swimming aw

dialogues.speaker: AND HEAVEN KNOWS WHAT LIVES WITHIN THAT POT
dialogues.text: A treasure chest sits on a reef, filled with the coins sh dropped in. They swim down to it, coins swirling around t in a current.

dialogues.speaker: THEY SEARCH THE WORLD FOR BURIED GOLD
dialogues.text: Georgie veers away from the others, diving through thick seagrass. He looks up. The Park Keeper stands before him, pointing sternly to a sign: “KEEP OFF THE SEAGRASS.” THEY WON’T GROW UP AND DON’T GROW OLD!

dialogues.speaker: CAN YOU IMAGINE THAT
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins grabs sponges from a colorful coral reef and tosses them to the children.  34 MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Be sure to scrub behind your ears! Mary Poppins floats up toward the surface as a SCHOOL OF DOLPHINS arrives and circles around the children, creatin whirlpool of bubbles. When the dolphins swim off and the bubbles clear, the children are thoroughly scrubbed and washed. The children are captured in enormous bubbles; on one, they float to the surface...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bubbles lift out of the water to hover above Mary Poppins, who sits in their bathtub, which is now floating an endless sea. Mary Poppins takes the beach umbrella, which sits in the and uses it to pop the children’s bubbles. They all land the tub.

dialogues.speaker: CAN YOU IMAGINE THAT
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins raises the umbrella for a sail, handing it t John.

dialogues.speaker: CAN YOU IMAGINE THAT
dialogues.text: The Admiral and Binnacle float past them in a rowboat.

dialogues.speaker: THEY SEE LIVING
dialogues.text: AS IT’S OWN REWARD

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: Ahoy!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: THEY ROCK THE BOAT, THEN — The Admiral and Binnacle salute. The children salute back John is pulled off balance by the umbrella and falls in.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: -— MAN OVERBOARD! Mary Poppins and the children reel John back onboard.  35

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE THE BLUE
dialogues.text: Yet...

dialogues.speaker: AND THEY SINK IN SECONDS FLAT
dialogues.text: So... PERHAPS WE’VE LEARNT WHEN DAY IS DONE

dialogues.speaker: CAN YOU I-MA-GINE THAT
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins pulls the string of the bathtub stopper. Wat rushes up through the drain, and a whirlpool opens up ben the tub. Everyone tumbles about as the tub spins down int the yawning vortex, spinning faster and faster...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. water swirling down the drain. The children are back the bathroom, wrapped in towels. All that’s left in the t is the toy duck. The children watch in mute awe as Mary Poppins picks it up and slips into her carpetbag, closing latch just as the song ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael pulls books off of shelves, searching for the sha document; Aunt Jane looks through the bottom drawer of th secretary desk, pulling out stacks of pencil drawings. Michael turns to Aunt Jane.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: No, just your drawings, and bills - and nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (After a beat: ) Then it’s not here. The children can be heard coming downstairs as Michael ta the drawings from Aunt Jane and tosses them onto the floo

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (Overlapping: ) Father, Aunt Jane! / You won’t believe it! / It was incredible!  36 The children appear in the doorway, Mary Poppins behind t

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: We went sailing!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Not now, please -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But it really happened! Tell them, Mary Poppins!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: I have no idea what you’re all talking about.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: We swam through a pirate ship -

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Enough - PLEASE! The children’s wonder has faded in an instant.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: You're right, father. We’re sorry. She takes Georgie’s hand and turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Contrite: ) No, wait - I’m sorry. I don’t mean to be cross with all of you. I’ve just lost something very important.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: And we'll find it. I’m sure your grandfather just tucked it away somewhere for safekeeping - (A realization: ) The bank! Didn’t father have a safety deposit box in the bank?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes, he did!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Well, let’s go!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s closed.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: We'll go first thing in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Won’t we need a key?  37

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: There’s a whole drawer full of keys up in father’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Is there?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Yes. Michael and Aunt Jane hurry out of the room. Mary Poppins shakes her head, dismayed at the mess they’ve left behind

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: My goodness, gracious, glory me! You'd think by now they’d have learned to pick up after themselves. As she picks up a piece of paper and drops it into the rubbish bin, the other papers on the floor magically RISE INTO THE AIR, swirl around the room, then collect themsel together and fall neatly into the rubbish bin. ONE FINAL DRAWING lands gently on top of the rest. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Cleaning is not a spectator sport, I‘1l remind you. John, Annabel, put all the books back on the shelves - (Handing Georgie the bin:) - Georgie Banks, come back here. Take out this rubbish, would you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Yes, Mary Poppins.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: There’s a good boy. Off you go, spit spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Georgie struggles to carry the bin, he pauses to look the final drawing that landed in the pile, which shows a playful depiction of the house in happier times, when mot was still alive. In the drawing, Father stands in front of the house with arms around John and Annabel and mother cradles Georgie i her arms. Everyone beams with happiness. Georgie takes th drawing out of the bin, folds it and puts it in his pocke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT - The next morning. It is raining; a se black umbrellas swirl along the sidewalk outside the bank  38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a safety deposit box. Michael flips through a sm stack papers as Aunt Jane watches. He finds nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well. That’s that. Michael puts everything back into the box and gestures fo BANK OFFICER to lock it away again.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: What about Mr. Dawes, Jr.? Couldn’t he give you more time?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m sure he would if he were still here. Dawes’ nephew has been running things lately. I’m not even sure he knows who I am.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (She rises, heading for the door:) Well, it’s high time he finds out, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Jane - ? Jane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time Michael leaves the vault, Aunt Jane is halfwa across the bank. He tries to get Aunt Jane’s attention as strides up the staircase at the far end of the main floor

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Whispered: ) Jane... Jane! INT. OUTSIDE MR. WILKINS’ OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: We can’t just charge into his office. Aunt Jane arrives at the desk of MISS PENNY FARTHING (30s Mr. Wilkins’ receptionist; Michael is not far behind.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Hello, Miss... (Off her name plaque:) .+. Penny Farthing, is it? Heavens, did the old secretary finally retire? (more)  39 AUNT JANE (cont'd) She always had that jar of sweets on the desk that we would raid as children - MR. WILKINS (50s, patrician, sporting a thin, waxed musta sticks his head out of his office, a kindly smile on his

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: I remember that jar - with those little toffees that stuck your teeth together. We must get you one of those jars, Miss Farthing.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FARTHING
dialogues.text: Of course, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: This wouldn’t happen to be your sister, would it, Mr. Banks?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Yes - Jane Banks. How do you do? They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Great pleasure to meet you -- William Weatherall Wilkins. (Waving them in:) Do step this way. Michael blinks, surprised. Aunt Jane smiles. INT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - DAY A SHORT TIME LATER: Wilkins sits at the desk, examining paperwork as Michael and Aunt Jane look on. He has an enormous office with a roaring fireplace and a view of Bi Ben out the window behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: If I had known George Banks’ son had taken a loan with us, I’d have handled the paperwork myself. Unfortunately, regarding the extension, there’s very little I can do at this point.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Our father did leave us shares in the bank. This is news to Wilkins. He looks up, smiling with intere

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Oh, well, that is good news.  40

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Yes, it is, but the trouble is, we can’t seem to find the share certificate.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t happen to have any record of our father’s shares, would you?

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: I would think so. (Tapping his intercom: ) Would you bring in the shareholder’s ledger, Miss Farthing?

dialogues.speaker: MISS FARTHING, (INTERCOM)
dialogues.text: Right away, Mr. Wilkins.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: What about your uncle, Mr. Dawes, Jr.? He would know if our father received shares, wouldn’t he? Wilkins sighs, gesturing to a portrait of his uncle.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: I'm afraid dear old Uncle Dawes is getting on in years. (He taps his temple.) “Non compos mentis"” - which, sadly, is why I had to take over for him. Ah - thank you, Miss Farthing. Miss Farthing has entered. She hands Wilkins the ledger a leaves. Wilkins flips pages, runs a finger along the colu Aunt Jane WILKINS (cont'd) Let’s see. Babcock, Baker. hmm. There’s no listing of George Banks here. But don’t despair. (Pointing out the window to Big Ben:) You still have until that big fellow out there chimes his last on Friday night to find that certificate. I'll keep searching here as well. and Michael rise.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you so much, Mr. Wilkins. They shake hands. As Michael and Aunt Jane head to the do  4l

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you. It was such a pleasure to meet you. Michael and Aunt Jane leave. Wilkins absently takes out h pocket watch, swinging it. He hits his intercom button.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Bring me all of George Banks’ old files, would you?

dialogues.speaker: MISS FARTHING, (INTERCOM)
dialogues.text: Of course, Mr. Wilkins. Wilkins walks round to his chair, swinging his pocket-wat and reopens the ledger. He turns to a page with the name GEORGE BANKS written in bold letters. He tears the page o and tosses it into the flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are already in bedclothes and robes when Mar Poppins enters, carrying a neatly-folded pile of children clothing. She sees Georgie jumping on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Georgie! This is a nursery, let me remind you, not a music hall.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Can we have another bath?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Oh, pish posh. (Turning: ) John, you'd best go downstairs and - CRASH! From downstairs comes the sound of breaking glass. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) - help Ellen put away the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yes, Mary Poppins. He goes. Mary Poppins heads for the wardrobe. Annabel intercepts her, reaching for the clothes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Here - I can put those away myself.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Very well. Mary Poppins glances to the broken kite which leans again Georgie’s bed. Sternly:  42 MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Georgie Banks - if you’re hoping I‘1l let you take this sadly- neglected kite to the park tomorrow, you had better start patching it up this instant.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (Smiling: ) Yes, Mary Poppins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen is on a chair, doing her best to put dishes on a hi shelf in the china cabinet. John enters just as Ellen is about to drop them.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Here - let me help you with those.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Oh - there’s a good lad. Such a help you are. (She kicks the broken plates away:) I only wish I could do somethin’ to ‘elp your father save this old house. (A beat. She considers.) I could sell my broach and necklace, I suppose - matching set, my old mum gave ‘em to me. Ellen picks up a large platter and holds it out to John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You'd do that for us? Ellen pulls the platter away and holds it to her chest.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What?? Sell my prized possessions?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh no, I didn’t mean it like that.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t worry. (She hands him the platter. Confidentially: ) I think they’re fakes, anyway. (hands over serving bowl) There’s plenty in this house worth more than them old trinkets. John stares at the china soup tureen he’s holding. He qui passes it back to Ellen and rushes out of the room.  43

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse me, Ellen -

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What’s got into ‘im?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie sits on his bed, Gillie at his side. He uses scis to cut up his father’s drawing of the family and patches kite with the pieces. Annabel is putting toys back in the chest when John comes rushing back in.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (With quiet urgency: ) Annabel - I know how to save the house!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Mary Poppins enters from her room, crossing to shut the drapes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: If you two are going to keep up all this whispering, I would like you to practice doing so as loudly as possible. It will still be bad manners, but at least then we’ll all be in on the secret. Mary Poppins notices Jack polishing one of the brass lamp the front portico of the house. She opens the window. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Hello, Jack! Jack smiles. He swings himself up onto the portico, climb along the ledge to the nursery window and onto the balcon

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins! How are you this fine evening?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Settling in quite nicely, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Climbing up:) Y’know, when I was a lad, I used to wave up to the boy and girl who lived here.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: You mean Michael and Jane.  44

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Miss Jane Banks, that’s right. I see Mr. Banks about now and again -— it’s been ages since I’ve seen her. Now that Mary Poppins’ back is turned, John taps Annabel the shoulder and hurries over to the mantelpiece. They ta in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: She lives in a flat on the other side of town now. I’m sure you’ll bump into her one of these days. Across the room: John takes the china bowl off the mantelpiece. It has an illustration of an autumn scene in park, with leaves falling from the trees. A carriage driv along a winding path. A CLYDESDALE HORSE in mid-gallop is hitched to the carriage. We see the COACHMAN from the bac he wears a top hat and high collar, and holds a whip in h hand.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Whispering: ) What are you doing? We’re not supposed to touch that.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Looking closely at the bowl: ) This is authentic Royal Doulton china, Annabel. Mother always said it was priceless, and I bet it’ll be enough to pay off father’s debt. Annabel grabs the bowl off John. He grabs it back from he

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: That’s a terrible idea, John. Mother loved that bowl.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But she’d sell it herself to save the house. Georgie sees John holding the bowl and hurries over.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: That was mother’s - put that back! (Grabbing for the bowl:) Put it back!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Here - give it to me. Jack now sits on the windowsill, chatting with Mary Poppi He lowers his voice, leaning in:  45

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It’s a good thing you come along when you did, Mary Poppins. As they tussle, the bowl slips and hits the floor, cracki it and breaking a wedge-shaped piece from the rim. JACK (cont'd) (Wincing: ) That didn’t sound good, now did it? John picks up the bowl. Mary Poppins doesn’t turn.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: What are the three of you up to? The children look at one another in a panic. John looks a the bowl, and sees a piece missing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (An urgent whisper: ) Give me the missing piece!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: I haven't got it!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well look for it then! John places the bowl back on the mantelpiece.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Which of you broke the bowl? The three turn back around. Mary Poppins stands before th Jack behind her. She holds the missing piece in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Georgie did.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I did not! It was Annabel.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: If John hadn't taken it off the mantel! The children all starting arguing at the same time. A voice comes from the bowl behind them.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST VOICE, (HORSE - 0O.S.)
dialogues.text: (Working-class accent: ) Actually, it was all three of them. The children turn, bewildered, glancing over to the door the window, wondering where the voices came from.  46

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Who said that? Mary Poppins walks up and peers at the bowl.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Oh, dear. They all peer at the bowl. THE ILLUSTRATION HAS CHANGED - crack has caused one of the carriage wheels to fall off, the carriage has tipped onto its axle. The Horse now star directly out of the bowl at the children, while the Coach peers down at the broken wheel.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Look - the picture’s changed. We see Mary Poppins and the group peering into the bowl f the horses’ “fish-eye lens” point of view.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: It looks as though they’ve broken your carriage wheel.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND VOICE, (COACHMAN - O.S.)
dialogues.text: (Irish accent: ) That they have. It’s useless now.

dialogues.speaker: HORSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Useless as a chocolate teapot.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: The bowl is speaking!

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And who do we think is going to fix that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Ay, there’s the riddle. Them what broke it fixes it. That’s what I say. What do you think, Mary Poppins?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (Irritated: ) I suppose we have no choice.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Wide-eyed: ) But how are we going to do that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I know a bit about fixing carriages.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: We can’t fix their carriage wheel. It isn’t possible!  47

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Everything is possible - even the impossible. Mary Poppins takes the bowl, sets it on a small table in center of the nursery and presses the missing piece back place. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Now, gather ‘round everyone - spit, spot! They do so. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Georgie, don’t forget Gillie! Are we ready?! The children watch in astonishment as Mary Poppins SPINS BOWL on the table. Colorful leaves fly out of the bowl in directions, filling the air and swirling around everyone, covering them completely. When the leaves fall away, they find themselves in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the ANIMATED WORLD of the Doulton china bowl. Jack an the children are stunned to discover they’re now wearing of-the-century dress. Mary Poppins holds an elegant paras While they are still very much real, everything around th is animated.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Wow!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What just happened?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Where are we? Jack lifts a finger, tapping the air behind him - we hear ‘tink, tink' of his finger against the bowl.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Looks like we’re in China, so to speak. Mary Poppins slides down a porcelain slope to the carriag

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Over here, everyone - this wheel won't fix itself. The others manage the slope much less gracefully;  48 MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Tread lightly, please - this is fine porcelain, we don’t want to chip the glaze. Georgie loses his balance completely and tumbles down to others. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Oh Georgie - head up and feet beneath you. (Turning to the carriage: ) Excuse me, driver, would you help us? The Coachman turns. The children see that he’s actually a IRISH SETTER in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: Well, Mary Poppins! Is it yourself?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But he’s - !

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: But you’re - !

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: That's right: I’m Irish - also part poodle. (barks ) Woof!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: How wonderful to see you, Shamus. So sorry about all this. Would you help Jack lift the carriage while the children put the wheel back on?

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: With pleasure!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (Amazed: ) She's talking to a dog!

dialogues.speaker: HORSE
dialogues.text: Well, of course she can talk!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Take your places, everyone. Ready? ... And LIFT! Jack and the Coachman lift the carriage. The children put wheel on. Mary Poppins uses her scarf to tie it in place.  49 MARY POPPINS (cont'd) (As she ties the scarf:) Let’s see now, this should do it. There we are - shipshape.

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: Not a bad job at all.

dialogues.speaker: HORSE
dialogues.text: S'pose it’1l have to do. Mary Poppins finishes tying the scarf around the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Back to the nursery we go.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Back already?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Can't we stay in the bowl for a while?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I want a carriage ride.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t mind one m’self.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: I suppose it wouldn’t do any harm. Shamus, would you mind?

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: Not in the least. Climb aboard, everyone!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL, JOHN AND GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Hooray!

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: (As they climb aboard: ) Mind the step. Plant yourselves comfy! Where would you all like to go this fine day?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: The Royal Doulton Music Hall, please.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: What’s that?  50

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: We’re on the brink of an adventure, children - don’t spoil it with too many questions.

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Clyde! The Coachman cracks his whip in the air and the horse tro along the cobblestones, hooves clanking on the china. “THE ROYAL DOULTON MUSIC HALL"

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hold on! The carriage climbs up the side of the bowl and turns ups down as it follows the path up the edge of the bowl and crosses over the lip.

dialogues.speaker: WHERE EACH DAY CROWDS MAKE THEIR WAY
dialogues.text: UPON THE SUN’S DESCENT

dialogues.speaker: NEVER QUITE LOGISTICAL TENT
dialogues.text: The carriage turns right side up again.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL DOULTON BOWL
dialogues.text: THERE’S A CUDDLY AND CURIOUS

dialogues.speaker: ANIMAL WATERING HOLE
dialogues.text: Two hummingbirds lands on Mary Poppins’ finger. She shows them to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: EVERY BEAST LARGE AND SMALL
dialogues.text: The hummingbirds flies away, leading us to an elegant fam walking along the path beside them; Jack and the children astounded to see beaks and snouts sticking out from under their parasols and top hats.

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: Nearly there, Mary Poppins! Georgie climbs to the front of the carriage and sits next Shamus. Jack sits across from Mary Poppins. They pass a giraffe riding a Penny Farthing. Georgie is amazed and shows Gillie the giraffe.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL DOULTON BOWL
dialogues.text: A gang of monkeys swing over the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: THERE’S A LOTTA BIRDS QUEUING UP (A monkey lands on Jack's head: )

dialogues.speaker: SCENERY THEY SWALLOW WHOLE
dialogues.text: Georgie swaps hats with Shamus.

dialogues.speaker: WAITING FOR THEIR BIG DRUM ROLL
dialogues.text: Elaborate gates open ahead of them.

dialogues.speaker: STANDING OVATION-AL
dialogues.text: They pass through the gates with the words “ROYAL DOULTON MUSIC HALL” scrolled into their ironwork.

dialogues.speaker: -.-MUSIC HALL
dialogues.text: The carriage comes to a stop in a large open space.

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: Here we are!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: But... where’s the music hall?  52

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Oh, yes - that. Silly me. Mary Poppins opens her parasol and spins it in the air. P BACK TO REVEAL that the parasol has transformed into an enormous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is now NIGHTTIME. Mary Poppins, Jack and the children themselves in line at the grand music hall tent, which is festooned with lights. The children are astounded.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN /ANNABEL/GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Wow!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: How on Earth did she do that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Shrugs: ) One thing you should know about Mary Poppins - she never explains anything.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hurry, hurry - only a few seats left! A WOLF with a thin waxed mustache acts as barker, swingin his pocket watch in a manner that makes him look suspicio like Wilkins. A BADGER and a WEASEL selling tickets behin him look remarkably like Gooding and Frye. WOLF (cont'd) Get tickets while you can for the one-night only, one and only - ! (Seeing her:) Mary Poppins! What an honor it is to have you join us this evening.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: And who's this I see? Why, it’s John, Annabel and Georgie Banks!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You know us?

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: Of course - everyone knows the Banks children.  53

dialogues.speaker: BADGER
dialogues.text: We've all been watching you in the nursery for years.

dialogues.speaker: WEASEL
dialogues.text: It’s so good to finally meet you.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: Hurry along now - get yourselves some peanuts and candy floss and go right on in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: May we, Mary Poppins?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Yes - just keep away from the edge of the bowl. They hurry off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, DANCING FLAMINGO SHOWGIRLS finish up the pre-show act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enthusiastic animal patrons fill the tiered seating that surrounds the stage. Mary Poppins, Jack and the children hurry to front-row seats. John sits down and immediately jumps up again. He turns t see a hedgehog family on the seat beneath him. Mr. Hedgeh doffs his cap. John smiles back and sits one seat in. Applause. Lights out. Drum roll. Rimshot - a spotlight hi center stage. The children are surprised to see Jack, who just next to them, now standing in the spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bucks and mares, cubs and does - welcome to our show of shows! Georgie places Gillie in Jack’s now-empty seat. JACK (cont'd) It is my great honor to introduce this evening’s renowned guest... the one, the only MARY POPPINS!  54 The crowd goes wild. Jack bounds to the front of the stag offer her his hand. Mary Poppins joins him onstage.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Sing for us, Mary Poppins!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: C’mon - have a go!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (Dismissively: ) Oh, I haven’t sung in years. Four “familiar” PENGUINS peak their heads out from the ce split of the stage curtains.

dialogues.speaker: PENGUINS
dialogues.text: Please, Mary Poppins? Please...

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: No, I couldn't possibly. (To the orangutan

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: D Flat Major. As she steps into the spotlight, the curtains part just enough to reveal a large, open book that acts as a dressi screen, with a bowler hat and hooked cane hanging on it. penguins push the set forward as Mary Poppins steps behin the screen and transforms into character. “BR COVER IS NOT THE BOOK” MARY POPPINS (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: HE SAID...
dialogues.text: The dressing screen flies out, revealing Mary Poppins in costume. The stage curtains open fully, revealing a set composed of piles of enormous books.

dialogues.speaker: FOR A COVER IS NICE BUT A COVER IS NOT THE BOOK
PENGUIN
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins, could you give us an example?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Certainly! An oversized book on stage magically opens, creating a Victorian “Pop-Up” set on which she performs. “NELLIE RUBINA" WAS MADE OF WOOD

dialogues.speaker: WELL, HER ROOTS WERE LUSH AND GREEN
dialogues.text: SO IN SPRING WHEN MR. HICK’RY SAW HER BLOSSOMS BLOOMIN’ THERE

dialogues.speaker: AND NOW THERE'S SEEDLINGS EVERYWHERE
dialogues.text: Jack slides down a book and joins her in the song and dan

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Shall we do the one about the “Wealthy Widow?”

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: By all means!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Always loved that one!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Oh go on then. A second book opens; another “Pop-Up” set appears.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHT ALL HER TREASURES TO A REEF
YOU'LL FIND YOUR FIRST IMPRESSION WAS MISTOOK
dialogues.text: (YA-DA-DA-DA)

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Give us the one about the “Dirty Rascal,” why don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Aside, worried: ) Isn't that one a bit long?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Well the quicker you’re into it, the quicker you’re out of it. The final “Pop-Up” book opens. Mary Poppins turns to the Conductor, tapping her cane on the stage in double time. tempo gets very fast. Jack, wide-eyed, launches into a “period rap” of sorts as he scales the set.

dialogues.speaker: SMALLER THAN A BIRDS
dialogues.text: (more)  57 JACK (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: PROCLAMATION/ "TO THE MISSUS AND THE MESSERS,/
dialogues.text: THE MORE OR LESSERS,/ BRING ME ALL THE LAND’S

dialogues.speaker: TO SING/ HE SAID "I'M THE DIRTY RASCAL/ AND I'M
dialogues.text: HERE TO TEACH THE KING!”

dialogues.speaker: FOUND A FRIEND/ AND THEY RAN ONTO A RAINBOW FOR
dialogues.text: THE STORY’S PERFECT END/

dialogues.speaker: IS THE SPECIAL STUFF INSIDE
dialogues.text: Jack reaches the top of the set as the audience cheers.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Hooray!... He did it! Mary Poppins bursts through the back of the pop-up set, rejoining Jack and leading the Penguins and a CHORUS LINE DANCING ANIMALS down a grand staircase.

dialogues.speaker: SO PLEASE LISTEN TO WHAT WE'VE SAID
JACK
dialogues.text: Sing it out strong...!

dialogues.speaker: LA-LA-LA
dialogues.text: The crowd cheers. In the audience, Georgie notices that Gillie is gone. He looks around; the Wolf is CASTING A LA SHADOW onto the canvas wall of the tent as he swings his pocket watch outside. The shadows of the Badger and the Weasel come into view as they cross back and forth carryi things. Georgie recognizes one of the items as Gillie.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Gillie! As Mary and Jack take their bows, Annabel suddenly realiz that Georgie is gone.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Where's Georgie?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
