dialogues.text: I don’t know. They look over just as he leaves through a tent flap. The panic and rush after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie comes out of the tent. The Wolf, Badger and Wease stand near a period moving van - a motorized cab with an fashioned steam engine that pulls a slatted wagon.  59 They are loading the wagon with all the real belongings f the children’s nursery (not animated).

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: Well, well - if it isn’t the boy who cracked the bowl. We've waited a long time for you Banks children to come and visit us - so we could pay a visit to your nursery.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: But those are our things!

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: Not anymore, they aren't.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Give Gillie back! Georgie rushes at the wagon, grabbing Gillie out of the b The Badger tries to grab it back, but Georgie won't let g GEORGIE (cont'd) He’s mine! My mother made him for me! John and Annabel run out from the tent, shouting.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Hey! Leave our brother alone! The Wolf cranks the engine and climbs into the cab.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: Time to go, boys! The Badger and the Weasel throw boy and giraffe together the wagon. They slam the slatted door and jump into the c The moving van roars off through the back gates, engulfin Annabel and John in exhaust smoke...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Annabel! Help! John!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL AND JOHN
dialogues.text: Georgie! John and Annabel chase after Georgie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +. down far darker, more ominous paths than the lovely cobblestone road that led up to the gates.  60

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We're coming Georgie!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (Shouts: ) Let me go! I want to go home!

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: (Calling back: ) What home? You’ve lost your home! The twins give chase, but the moving van is getting away they slow down, exhausted, when suddenly the carriage dri by the Coachman appears out of the shadows behind them. John and Annabel gasp. A hand reaches down and pulls them into the carriage. Sea turns around to them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Shamus!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Clyde!

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: That's right - it’s us!

dialogues.speaker: HORSE
dialogues.text: Let’s go get your brother back! The chase is on. The two vehicles screech and slide on th china’s glazed surface.

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: We're gaining on them!

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: Give it more speed! The Badger shovels more coal into the steam engine. As th van banks up the side of the bowl, Georgie is thrown to t side of the tipping wagon. The carriage is closing in.

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: Giddy up, big fella! The carriage tips and drives up the side of the bowl. The Wolf swerves left and right cutting them off. The carriag closes the gap. COACHMAN (cont'd) (To horse: ) Almost there. John reaches out to Georgie.  61

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Georgie! The carriage manages to pull alongside the moving van. Th twins ready themselves. JOHN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: READY, AND
dialogues.text: - and they leap onto the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: Well done children!

dialogues.speaker: HORSE
dialogues.text: Give ‘em what for! The carriage recedes into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: Get rid of them!

dialogues.speaker: WEASEL
dialogues.text: But, sir -

dialogues.speaker: WOLF
dialogues.text: You heard me! The Weasel and the Badger climb out and crawl towards the children. John and Annabel look down at Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Oh Georgie! Are you alright? John looks up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Annabel, look. Annabel turns and sees the Badger and Weasel closing in. reaches down, grabs a cricket bat from the nursery belong and swings at the Weasel. The bat misses them and goes flying, chipping the bowl. The chip hits the Badger, who slams into the Weasel, knocking both off the wagon. JOHN (cont'd) (To Annabel: ) Stay with Georgie. Annabel lowers herself into the wagon. She hugs Georgie. watch as John crawls forward.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Be careful!  62

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing? John pulls out the pin, detaching the wagon from the cab.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: He did it! John makes his way along the bar back towards the wagon a climbs into the carriage. The Wolf grabs the stoking shovel and swings it hard, hit the bowl and creating a deep crack in the bowl which trav towards the children’s wagon. The wagon wheel hits the crack which splinters off. They up the side of the bowl like a runaway roller coaster. Th Wolf loses control of the cab and careens off a bridge in the water. The frightened children see an ominous sign ahead: “Cauti Edge of Bowl!” ANNABEL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: THE EDGE OF THE BOWL
dialogues.text: The children scream as the wagon flies off the edge. They fall into space, twisting and turning in slow motion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie is in his bed, back in his nightclothes again. He tosses and turns in his sleep. Mary Poppins sits next to

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: It’s alright, Georgie, it’s alright. You were been having a nice sort of nightmare, I must say. Mary Poppins turns on his bedside lamp.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: You were right, Mary Poppins! A cover is not the book! We thought they were nice, but they were mean!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Whatever are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: They tried to take Gillie!  63

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Gillie is right here, sleeping - as you should be. She moves the giraffe next to Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: But it was real! They stole all our things, and the wolf said we were never going to see our home again.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: That’s absurd. Mary Poppins stands goes to shut the window. She sees Jac cycling away outside, he waves up to her as he goes. John Annabel climb out of their beds, awake as well.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But I had a nightmare like that, too.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Turning on light:) So did I. It seemed awfully real.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to lose our home. Georgie moves over and sits on Annabel’s bed, cuddling Gillie.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You see, Georgie? That’s why we wanted mother’s bowl; we were going to sell it to save the house.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (After a beat.) I miss mother. The room falls silent. Something flickers ever so briefly Mary Poppins’ eyes, and then she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Listen to the three of you. You’re all worrying far too much. After all, you can’t lose what you’ve never lost.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. “THE PLACE WHERE LOST THINGS GO"

dialogues.speaker: JUST BETWEEN THE DARK AND THE MORNING LIGHT
dialogues.text: (more)  64 MARY POPPINS (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: ONLY OUT OF PLACE...
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins puts John back to bed and tucks him in. She tucks Annabel into her bed.

dialogues.speaker: HIDING IN THE PLACE WHERE THE LOST THINGS GO
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins takes Georgie’s hand and leads him back to b Now, time to get some sleep. And in the morning, bright and early, we'll take that bowl to my cousin and have it mended. (She tucks Georgie in.)

dialogues.speaker: GONE BUT NOT FORGOTTEN IS THE PERFECT PHRASE
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins walks over to the window, looking out toward bright star in the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: FIND HER IN THE PLACE WHERE THE LOST THINGS GO
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins walks out of the nursery, closing the pocket doors that lead to her room. Annabel, gets up, crossing t look out the window at the star.  65 After a moment, she turns to go back to bed, but then she notices the bowl on the mantelpiece. She peers at it, her eyes growing wide.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Quiet wonder: ) John... look! Mary Poppins’ scarf. It wasn’t a dream after all... John crosses to Annabel’s side. She points at the carriag the bowl; Mary Poppins' scarf is tied around the broken wheel. John is amazed.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Shall we tell her?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: We'd better not. I expect she already knows. INT. MARY POPPINS’ BEDROOM —- CONTINUOUS Mary Poppins peers into the nursery through the glass in pocket doors, having quietly listened to this last exchan Satisfied, she steps away from the doors. EXT. ADMIRAL BOOM’S ROOFTOP/ HOUSE AT 17 CHERRY TREE LANE

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Aunt Jane walks up the lane to the family home, carrying rally flyers; Jack is dousing the street-lamp in front of house. The door opens on the roof of the Admiral’s house. Binnacle pushes the Admiral out and blows his whistle. Big Ben begins to toll 8 a.m. The Admiral is enraged.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: Blast the devil - too soon! Why can’t those pea-brained, Big Ben buffoons get it right?! (Noticing Aunt Jane:) Ahoy, fair lady!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (Turning to wave:) Good morning! She turns back around just as Jack slides down the lamp p The two collide, Aunt Jane’s flyers going everywhere. AUNT JANE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh, dear - I am so sorry, miss!  66 He scrambles to help her pick them up.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s alright - thank you - Mary Poppins appears at the nursery window above.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Good morning, Jane - I see you’ve bumped into Jack. The children and I are heading into town to get something fixed. Would you like to come with us?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Work calls, I'm afraid. We have a rally today.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: That's right. You ought to give Jack one of those flyers. Mary Poppins disappears from the window. As Jack continue rescuing Aunt Jane’s flyers:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're Miss Banks, aren’t you? I don’t know if you remember me, but I used to wave to you when I’d see you up there in that very window. In the background, Ellen peers through the letter box.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (Smiling: ) Why, yes - Jack. I remember. Call me Jane, please.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ‘Course I was much younger then -

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: True - but your smile hasn’t changed a bit. (She hands him a flyer.) It’s this afternoon, if you can come.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: SPRUCE, eh? Good for you, Jane Banks - all us lamplighters know what a fine job you’re doing for the workers.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: We do our best.  67

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You ever need a ladder raised or a lamp lit, consider it done.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Why thank you, Jack - Thank you. INT. THE BANKS FRONT ENTRY HALL — CONTINUOUS Ellen is still peering out through the letter box at Jack Aunt Jane when Mary Poppins comes down the stairs carryin the Royal Doulton bowl in a cloth bag. She comes up behin Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Polishing the keyhole?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Look at that: Miss Jane’s chattin’ with that ‘andsome lamplighter - looks as though he’s lit ‘er up as well, don’t it? Not that anythin’1l ever come of it - she says that ship has sailed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: And I say there are always other ships. Michael rushes down the stairs with his briefcase, panick

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: My alarm clock didn’t ring!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Oh, dear - let me help you. Mary Poppins puts the bowl down on a side table and TAKES MICHAEL'S BRIEFCASE, handing it to Ellen. Michael gets hi coat from the rack and puts it on while Mary Poppins retrieves his hat and umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m going to be late! That’s all I need. Mary Poppins hands him only his hat and umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: You’re not late yet. Off you go! Mary Poppins opens the door as Michael runs out.  68

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael hurries out the front door of the house, barely noticing Jack and Aunt Jane as he passes them. An ELEGANT WOMAN approaches from the opposite direction, holding a p of paper with an address on it.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Glancing back: ) Hello - I have to run, forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Watch where you're going! Michael nearly runs into the ELEGANT WOMAN on the sidewal

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Sorry, excuse me — He dodges the woman and hurries off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) Michael!

dialogues.speaker: ELEGANT WOMAN
dialogues.text: No it’s fine. I’m looking for number nineteen...

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE AND JACK
dialogues.text: (together) Just two doors down. They share a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ELEGANT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Many thanks. Sincerely. As the Elegant Woman continues on her way, Ellen rushes o holding his briefcase, followed by Mary Poppins, carrying bowl, and the children.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Michael - your briefcase! (Too late. He’s gone.) He’d leave his ‘ead on the breakfast table if it weren’t screwed on.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Here - I'll take the briefcase. The children and I are heading that way on an errand; we can stop by the bank afterwards.  69

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'll give you a lift. My rounds are done. He turns his ladder sideways, setting it astride and fastening it to the rear fender of the bike. He buckles i up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: All aboard - come on.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: On the bicycle?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: But there are five of us. We can’t all fit.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: The weight on those wheels alone - Mary Poppins, how much do you weigh?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: How...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Quickly interceding. ) Never you mind about that - it’s a question of balance. Jack kicks off the bike guard as Mary Poppins puts the briefcase in the front basket then holds the bicycle stea JACK (cont'd) (He lifts Annabel onto the bike.) Annabel here, and then John here. He balances them on one side of the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Careful!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (To the twins.) Sit up straight. You're not flour bags.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Georgie, you’re up front... (He sets Georgie on top of the briefcase.) And Mary Poppins, you here...  70

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Thank you. Mary Poppins hops up onto the other side as Jack gets on bike. ON THE ROOFTOP —

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: Primed and ready, Mr. Binnacle?

dialogues.speaker: BINNACLE
dialogues.text: Ready and charged, sir. DOWN BELOW -—

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Ready everyone?

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Ready!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (To Mary Poppins: ) Are you sure this is quite safe?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Not in the slightest. Ready!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Steady... ON THE ROOFTOP —

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: Three, two, one... FIRE!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Go! BOOM! Jack launches forward. The bike teeters, looking ce to crash, then Jack gets it under control and pedals off. EXT. THE STREET IN FRONT OF COUSIN TOPSY’S SHOP - DAY Jack, Mary Poppins and the children ride the precarious bicycle along a city street.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Pull over right ahead. Thank you, Jack. Jack stops at the entrance to a narrow alley. Mary Poppin takes the bowl as Jack helps the children off the bike. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Off we go, jiggity-jog!  71 EXT. THE ALLEYWAY, COUSIN TOPSY’S SHOP They go down a narrow alleyway past a series of eccentric looking shops.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Never noticed this alley before.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Clearly you’ve never had a Royal Doulton bowl that wanted mending. (Gestures: ) Straight ahead. They arrive at Topsy’s repair shop - a little house at th end with a front door so low that everyone except Georgie would have to duck to go inside. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Here we are. Annabel reads the sign that hangs above the little door:

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: “TOPOTREPOLOVSKY’S - All Repairs Large and Small Fix-it Shop.”

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Looks as though it’s just a Small Fix-it Shop today.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: That’s just what we want. The bowl only needs a small fix, after all. She raps on the door with the parrot head of her umbrella

dialogues.speaker: PARROT UMBRELLA
dialogues.text: So now my head is a door knocker? I suppose my beak might be useful for opening cans —

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: “Fuss, fuss, fuss” - don’t be so dramatic. Mary Poppins raps on the door again, hears nothing. She pushes the tip of the umbrella through the letter box. MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Cousin Topsy?

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (A strangely untraceable Eastern European accent: ) Mary Poppins - NO! For the love of all that is holy, do not come in!  72

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Don’t be so rude!

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please stay away, - it is Second Wednesday today!

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Second Wednesday... Oh dear, I'd forgotten. Still, today or never - that’s my motto. Mary Poppins forces the tip of the cane into the keyhole thwacks the parrot on the top of the head.

dialogues.speaker: PARROT UMBRELLA
dialogues.text: Ouch! She twists the umbrella, opening the lock, and goes insid

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (To the others: ) There we are. INT. TOPSY’S WORKSHOP - CONTINUOUS They pass through the tiny door into a narrow entry hall, workshop just ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (Annoyed: ) So in you come. You do not listen to Topsy. Mary reaches the doorway to the workshop. Almost instantly, the entire room begins to rotate, FLIPP UPSIDE DOWN. Nearly everything stays stuck in place. TOPSY (dramatic, Bohemian, a restorations artist of the highest order) is at the top of a spiral staircase on the side of the room; she grips the railings as the room spin TOPSY (cont'd) Oh, no - it has begun! The room comes to a stop with the floor where the ceiling should be. Topsy now sits on the ceiling. A chandelier ju up like a fountain in the middle of the room. TOPSY (cont'd) Now, what do you want?  73

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: You have guests, cousin. You might at least greet them at the door.

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: And how am I to do that, please, when I am down here up on the ceiling?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (With a sigh:) Very well, we will come to you. Excuse me please, Georgie. (To the children: ) Now this way please. Be very careful on the way - up. Mary Poppins makes her way gracefully down the piles of broken things, the children and Jack following her.

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: Why be careful? Leave it all for Topsy to fix. Climb on my shelves, step on the toys, kick the little china dolls in their faces -

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: John, Annabel, Georgie and Jack - this is my cousin -

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: Second cousin - many times removed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Tatiana Antanasia Cositori Topotrepolovsky.

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: But you may call me Topsy.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (To Topsy: ) That’s an unusual accent you’ve got there - where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: Well, it’s an interesting story...

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (Cuts her off:) We have no idea. (Taking the bowl: ) We need you to fix this bowl, dear.

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: (Reeling back: ) No, no, no no - } (more)  74 TOPSY (cont'd) It is, as I have told to you, the second Wednesday of the month, when everything is turning turtle.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Turning turtle? What exactly does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: It means my whole world goes flippity-flop like a turtle on its back and I don’t know my up from my down, my East from my West - (Flirting with Jack:) - my Topsy from my bottom-sy -

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Yes, I think we’ve all grasped the concept.

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: Oh, good. That’s quick for you. Topsy picks up an instrument that has been badly repaired shows it to the children. TOPSY (cont'd) You see, my little ones? Anything I fix on Second Wednesday goes kerflooey.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (Rolling her eyes:) Kerflooey...

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: (Nods, grim: ) Yes. Kerflooey. Topsy throws the instrument across the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Please, cousin, you’ve always said you could fix anything -

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: (Turning to Annabel: ) Sweet girl - you tell Mary Poppins, who doesn’t listen, that any other day, Tatiana Antanasia Cositori Topotrepolovsky can fix anything... “TURNING TURTLE”

dialogues.speaker: I WILL MEND, AND THEN SPEND THE DAY IN BED
dialogues.text: (more)  No 75 TOPSY (cont'd) CHILDREN, “SATUR”, “SUN”, AND “MON”DAYS

dialogues.speaker: COMES THE "TOPSY GETS BAD NEWS" DAY
dialogues.text: IT’S THE DREADED SECOND WEDNESDAY!!

dialogues.speaker: AND ALL BECAUSE THE WORLD IS TURNING TURTLE
dialogues.text: (Mary Poppins tries to hand Topsy the bowl - she waves it away.)

dialogues.speaker: BLACK IS WHITE, THIN IS FAT
dialogues.text: (AND THAT IS WHY I'M LOOSENING UP MY GIRDLE!)

dialogues.speaker: I CANNOT HELP THIS CHARMING TROUPE
dialogues.text: DON'T MOCK ME CAUSE I’M IN THE SOUP

dialogues.speaker: NOW MY LIFE RESEMBLES "WAR AND PEACE"
dialogues.text: (THAT TOLSTOY CERTAINLY HAD THE GIFT OF GAB!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't get through it!

dialogues.speaker: IF THIS KEEPS UP I'LL DIG A HOLE
dialogues.text: YOU SAY LIFE’S A CHERRY BOWL

dialogues.speaker: BUT WEDNESDAYS IS FULL OF PITS
JACK
dialogues.text: (Holding up a drum:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Holding a clarinet:)

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Picking up a cracked bass: )

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: LET’S DO “THE TURTLE SWING!” They all play a hot jazz chorus - with John on bass, Anna on violin, Georgie on xylophone and Jack going wild on th drums. Mary Poppins conducts; Topsy dances like a whirlin dervish. Soon they are all dancing. As the music builds, Topsy floats up in the air and lands on her head, upside and thoroughly distraught. TOPSY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: OH, WOE IS ME
dialogues.text: NOW I’M ON MY HEAD

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: Lucky me?!?

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: I love your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: You see? When your world turns upside down, the best thing is to turn right along with it.  77

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: Oh, I do see! From down here, things look right side up. She laughs, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I wouldn't mind seeing things from that angle.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Sounds like fun.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Can we?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Very well. Flippity-flop. Mary Poppins tosses her umbrella into the air and everyon flips onto their heads.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: «+. THERE!

dialogues.speaker: WELL, KNOCK ON WOOD, MY DEAR.
dialogues.text: Mary’s parrot-headed umbrella lands next to Mary Poppins. MARY POPPINS (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: THE THINGS YOU VIEW WILL CHANGE FOR GOOD
dialogues.text: Topsy flips back onto her feet. The others follow.

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: (A light bulb moment: )

dialogues.speaker: SHE NEVER THOUGHT OF THINGS THAT WAY
TURTLE
dialogues.text: Topsy reaches for the bowl. Jack hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: Come. Give your bowl to me. No more am I afraid with this new point of view.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Good!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (To Topsy: ) Excuse me, but do you have any idea how much our bowl might be worth?

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: In money? (She looks at the bowl, considers for a moment: ) Not very much, I’m afraid. But that doesn’t make it any less beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: But our mother said it was priceless.

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: Yes, I am sure it was - to her. Disappointment is visible in the eyes of all three childr TOPSY (cont'd) Mary Poppins is right - for once. It is all in the way you look at things.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Thank you cousin. Now come along, children. Get your hats. The children all collect their hats and head out.  79

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: And don’t you worry about mother’s bowl. I will fix and make perfect for you. So you come back maybe next second Wednesday!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, spit-spot!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you, “Topsy Turvy.”

dialogues.speaker: TOPSY
dialogues.text: “Topsy Turvy” - I like it! It’s catchy. EXT. THE ALLEYWAY, COUSIN TOPSY’S SHOP - DAY Mary Poppins and Jack come out of the alleyway, the child lagging behind, the twins talking quietly to one another.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Now what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Well, like Topsy said, maybe we should start looking at things differently - Everyone looks back as they hear LOUD CREAKS AND CRASHES coming from inside Topsy’s shop. Mary Poppins turns back continues walking.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Marvelous. It looks as though things are starting to turn around for my cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, Mary Poppins and the children ride down the street.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins, this is not the quickest way to the bank.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (Curtly: ) Well it is today.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Look, there’s Aunt Jane!  80

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Aunt Jane! Aunt Jane walks just ahead, carrying arm-loads of rally posters and banners. Jack pulls over, the children waving

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Off to the rally, are you, Jane?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Yes - hello, everyone! All still here thank goodness. No one fell off.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Say, I could come back and give you a hand with all that once I’ve dropped the others at the bank.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Oh no, no - please don’t worry. I’m perfectly fine. Really.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Oh, nonsense. The bank is just around the corner, and the children and I have plenty of legs to get us there. Climb off, everyone - ready, and - jump. They do. Jack takes the banners and posters from Aunt Jan tying them to the back of the bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don’t mind, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Of course not. I was hoping to stop by that rally of yours, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: You were? Oh, good!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: You should ride up in the front basket.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I think she’1ll be better here. Up you go now!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Here, is it? Yes. Jack helps Aunt Jane sit side-saddle on the bar of the bicycle in front of him.  81 AUNT JANE (cont'd) Where should I hold on?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (To Aunt Jane:) Ready?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Yes, as ready as I’ll ever be. Oh-! Aunt Jane bursts out laughing, holding on for dear life a Jack pedals off down the street. Mary Poppins and the children watch them cycling away together before Mary Poppins decides-—

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Right, that’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT - Outside, the bank is thronged with people as Poppins leads the children up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Step along, children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, the bank is a beehive of activity. Mary Poppins enters with the children and strides purposefully toward Information Desk, the children hurrying to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Walking with Annabel: ) There must be someone at this bank who could help us save our house.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: I’m sure father has already asked.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Well, we haven't. Maybe we can get them to see things from a new point of view.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Sit over there children. Mary Poppins guides the children over to a bench, gesture for them to sit, then crosses to the INFORMATION DESK CLE MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Good afternoon, I’m looking for Mr.- A POSTMAN interrupts, his arms full of parcels.  82

dialogues.speaker: POSTMAN
dialogues.text: I‘1l need a signature for these, sir.

dialogues.speaker: INFORMATION DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Of course - excuse me a moment. Mary Poppins purses her lips, nettled. As she waits, she adjusts her hat, gazing into the reflection of a brass la ON THE REFLECTION: The children are visible. Gooding and also appear, having just entered the bank. Frye sees Georgie, smiles and waves. Georgie waves back. Annabel pointedly pushes Georgie’s hand down. Frye’s smil disappears; his face clouds with guilt as he follows Good upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (To Annabel: ) What did you do that for? You hurt his feelings.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: You do know who those men are, don’t you, Georgie?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: They're the lawyers. He’s the nice one. A beat. Annabel turns to John.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Maybe we could convince him to help us.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Worth a try. (Glancing to the stairs:) Today or never. That’s my motto. C'mon. ON THE REFLECTION: Mary Poppins watches the children as t lean in together, clearly plotting something. The postman leaves, and the clerk turns back to Mary Popp

dialogues.speaker: INFORMATION DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Now, how may I help you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Finally. I'd like to see Mr. Michael Banks... ON THE REFLECTION: the children sneak off.  83 INT. STAIRCASE/OUTSIDE WILKINS’ OFFICE - DAY The children hurry up the stairs, following Gooding and F who turn at the top of the steps and disappear around the corner. The children sneak around the corner in pursuit, spying on the lawyers as they go into Wilkins’ office. Mi Farthing sees them.

dialogues.speaker: MISS FARTHING
dialogues.text: Is there something I can do for you, children? The twins freeze; Georgie, though, sees the new jar of toffees on Miss Farthing’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: May I have a sweet, please?

dialogues.speaker: MISS FARTHING
dialogues.text: Yes of course, dear. You all can. She takes the lid off the jar, gesturing for them to come over. As they do so, the muffled voices of Wilkins and th lawyers can be heard emanating from behind the office doo

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Mrs. Clara Corry, 42 Chatsworth Way.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: Evicted.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Mr. Wallace Trimlet, 96 Digby Crescent.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: In foreclosure.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Mr. Michael Banks, 17 Cherry Tree Lane.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: In foreclosure.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Miss Muriel Brighton-Jones -— INT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: How many repossessions so far this month?  84

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: 19, sir - and we have nearly that amount scheduled for next week alone.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Who would have thought this Slump would be so good for business, eh?

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: (Gathering his courage: ) I wonder, Mr. Wilkins, if, perhaps, as Michael Banks is an employee, you might consider giving him a few more weeks to pay off his loan.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: And lose our chance to get that house? I don't like to lose, Mr. Frye. (Hitting the intercom: ) Didn't I ask for tea, Miss Farthing? INT/EXT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: MISS FARTHING
dialogues.text: (On the intercom: ) Yes, sir. Right away, Mr. Wilkins. (To the children: ) Why don’t you all help yourselves? Miss Farthing goes off to get the tea. The children creep over to Wilkins' door. Annabel points to the sign on it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (Whispering: ) “Office of the Bank Chairman.” We can’t go in there. The children peer through the crack in the door, listenin

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: (Nervously: ) It’s just that, well, his family has suffered tremendous hardship this past year, and -

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: You're not giving Banks one second longer to pay off that loan - do I make myself clear? Wilkins swings his pocket watch. From Georgie’s POV, he c see Wilkins’ shadow on the wall - as the firelight flicke it changes into THE ANIMATED SHADOW HE SAW ON THE CIRCUS and back again.  85

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Look!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: It’s the wolf!

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In two days Banks will be out on that street and the house will be ours. Georgie shoves the door open and charges into the office.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Georgie, no!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: You can’t steal our house! I’m telling my father!

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Steal your - ? Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: These are the Banks children.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: ... Are they? (He smiles. To Georgie: ) Come here, boy. I think you may have misunderstood -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Georgie!

dialogues.speaker: RUN
dialogues.text: Miss Farthing backs in, carrying a large tea tray.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Close that door, Miss Farthing. Georgie and the twins race past Miss Farthing, ducking beneath the tea tray, nearly sending it flying. WILKINS (cont'd) Fool! STOP THEM! Miss Farthing wheels round, trying not to spill the tea, kicking the door closed after Frye. Gooding slams into th closed door.  86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael comes out into the lobby, where Mary Poppins wait for him. She holds out his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Ah, there you are Michael. The children and I brought you your briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. But... where are the children? The children come racing down the stairs, with Gooding, F and Wilkins close behind.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What is it? What’s happened?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (Pointing back: ) He’s the wolf trying to steal our house!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What on Earth are you talking about? Wilkins crosses directly to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: I'm afraid your children burst into my office just now, Banks -

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What??

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: I was just seeing if anything could be done about extending your loan, when they came in claiming I was trying to steal your house.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: He is - we heard him!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Wilkins is trying to help us!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Then why was he chasing us? Wilkins digs into a pocket, pulling out a handful of toff  87

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: I just thought they might stop running about and making a scene if I offered them some sweets.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I am so sorry, Mr. Wilkins.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Let’s just see it doesn’t happen again - He places a toffee in Georgie’s hand, one in John’s and o in Annabel’s. WILKINS (cont'd) (To the children: ) After all, you don’t want your father losing his position on account of you, now do you? (Stepping close to Michael, kindly: ) Now, I know time is running short, Banks, but I want you to have every chance to pay off that loan - I'll stay in my office on Friday evening until the last stroke of midnight, you have my word.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: (Turning to the lawyers: ) Gentlemen - He gestures for them to follow him upstairs. As they go:

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (To her father: ) But Father, he really did it -

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Not another word! (to Mary Poppins) Take them home this instant. We’1l discuss this when I get back.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Come along, children. Michael watches as Mary Poppins leads them out. He turns away, tense, then goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 88 Damp, grey fog settles over London as Mary Poppins and th children return home. The children walk ahead of their na

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Now we’ve done it, haven't we? I don’t think I’ve ever seen father that upset with us before.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: But we were telling the truth!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: That doesn’t matter, Georgie. We got him into trouble - and he doesn’t even know we broke mother’s bowl.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Everything we’ve tried to fix, we've only made worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children walk through the fog, deep in thought. Mary Poppins follows behind. They come to a crossroads. Annabel pauses, looking around The fog is getting so thick it’s difficult to make out th buildings around them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Which way do we go, Mary Poppins?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Why would you ask me? The three of you are leading the way, after all.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Us?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But we were -

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: - walking around in a fog.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: No, we weren’t - I mean, yes, we are in a fog - but -

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: - we were only talking.  89

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Yes - too focused on where you’ve been to pay attention to where you're going.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: But father told us to go straight home!

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: He'll be furious if we’re late.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Not much to be done about that now, is there?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (Worried: ) Are we lost, then?

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That would depend on where you want to go. A light appears through the fog. Jack smiles down at them from a streetlamp that hangs from an archway behind them.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN/ANNABEL/GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: At your service. Jack climbs halfway down and sits on a ledge just above M Poppins and the children, peering down at them. JACK (cont'd) Say, what’s with all the glum faces? Lost sixpence and found a penny?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: We've made a mess of everything.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Father’s furious with us.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: And we can’t find our way home.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Not believing it:) “Lost” - are you, Mary Poppins?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Hopelessly.  90

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well now, I’m no expert, but if ever I lose my way, I just look for a little light to guide me. “TRIP A LITTLE LIGHT FANTASTIC” LET’S SAY YOU'RE LOST IN A PARK,

dialogues.speaker: OR... YOU CAN TRIP A LITTLE LIGHT FANTASTIC WITH ME
dialogues.text: WHEN YOU’RE ALONE IN YOUR ROOM

dialogues.speaker: THEN YOU CAN ALWAYS FIND THE WAY
dialogues.text: SO WHEN LIFE IS GETTIN’ DREARY JUST PRETEND THAT YOU'RE A “LEERIE”

dialogues.speaker: AS YOU TRIP A LITTLE LIGHT FANTASTIC WITH ME
dialogues.text: Jack jumps onto a lamppost.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What’s a leerie?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Why, it’s what we lamplighters call ourselves, of course. He flickers the streetlamp on and off in a rhythmic patte JACK (cont'd) Time to send out the call to arms: “Leeries, trip the lights and lead the way.” As a Leerie lights his lamp, we DROP DOWN to find Jack leading the group through the foggy streets like the Pied Piper. He steers the children up curbs and around pillar boxes.

dialogues.speaker: OR YOU CAN TRIP A LITTLE LIGHT FANTASTIC WITH ME
dialogues.text: Ahead, lights continue to flicker on, lighting their way. by one, leeries appear out of the fog, gazing down from lampposts, acknowledging the children as they pass.  91 JACK (cont'd) AND WHEN THE FOG COMES ROLLIN’ IN

dialogues.speaker: DON'T LET IT BE YOUR EPITAPH
dialogues.text: SO WHEN LIFE IS GETTIN’ SCARY

dialogues.speaker: UNTIL THE DAWN
dialogues.text: IT’S DARKEST RIGHT BEFORE THE LIGHT... They come to a dead end. A lamppost with an ornate base stands before them.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Now what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Just as Jack said - we follow the light. She steps onto the base of the lamp, which magically disappears into the ground, creating an unusually LONG LAMPPOST. One by one, they all follow her, sliding down t post like it’s a FIREMAN’S POLE. They arrive at the entra to a drainpipe and duck into it. The leeries voices echo inside the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: AS YOU...
dialogues.text: 92 JACK (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: TRIP A LITTLE LIGHT FANTASTIC WITH ME
dialogues.text: Jack, Mary Poppins and the children arrive at... EXT. AN ABANDONED PARK — CONTINUOUS An abandoned park with an unused fountain at its center, shrouded in darkness. The street lamps and pathways of th park are silhouetted only by moonlight. One by one, gas lamps flick on, revealing leeries on ever lamppost - until the entire park is glowing with brillian light. DANCE SEQUENCE - which includes Jack and all the leeries spinning on lampposts and performing spectacular stunts o their bicycles. The Leeries all dance round their lamp posts, jumping on off. Jack joins them, tipping his hat to Angus and the other Leeries. Jack and a small group of Leeries dance in front Mary Poppins and the children. They join the other Leeries on lamp posts as other Leerie bikes perform amazing stunts and parkour over traveling ladders, followed by a ladder section. Jack, Angus and the crew dance, jumping up and spinning r the lamp posts. At the end of it, ANGUS bounds over to the children.

dialogues.speaker: ANGUS
dialogues.text: Come along - join us in a bit of kick and prance.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Kick and prance - it means “dance.” It’s leerie speak. You don’t say the word you mean; you say something that rhymes, only - (It’s hard to describe: ) Here, I’1l show you how it works. Angus...

dialogues.speaker: GIVE US YOUR WEEP AND WAIL
dialogues.text: (more)  93 JACK (cont'd) (To the children, aside:) TO THE REST OF YA, THAT MEANS: “TALE”

dialogues.speaker: ANGUS
dialogues.text: THEN I PINCHED WHAT’S FATTER

dialogues.speaker: TO WORK
dialogues.text: You see? There’s nothing to it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Can you speak leerie, Mary Poppins?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (A wide-eyed glance: ) Can I speak leerie?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Of course she can. She’s Mary Poppins!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Can we do it with you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL AND JOHN
dialogues.text: Please?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Oh, very well then.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Children...

dialogues.speaker: GIVE US YOUR WEEP AND WAIL
JOHN
dialogues.text: Well... WE HAD THIS BOWL...

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: (Loudly: )

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Softly: ) BUT THEY TRIPPED THE LIGHT...

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: (Mimicking him: )

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: (Explosive: ) LET’S TRIP A LITTLE LIGHT FANTASTIC! The children join in the number, dancing round the founta with the Leeries as Mary Poppins looks on from up top. The Leeries all surround Mary Poppins on the fountain.

dialogues.speaker: THE LEERIES
dialogues.text: Join us Mary Poppins! Mary Poppins is lifted off the fountain and joins in the number with the Leeries... At the end of which, she perfo an amazing bike spin and magically turns on the fountain.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You've got it - now let’s get you all back home! Jack and the leeries lead Mary Poppins and the children o of the park.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: NOW IF YOUR LIFE IS GETTIN’ FOGGY THAT’S NO REASON TO COMPLAIN

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: THERE’S SO MUCH IN STORE

dialogues.speaker: OF 17 CHERRY TREE LANE
dialogues.text: Jack tosses his leerie pole into the air, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. catches it on Cherry Tree Lane. They continue through fog toward the house, the leerie’s poles lit to help guid the way.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: WON’T YOU...

dialogues.speaker: TRIP A LITTLE LIGHT FANTASTIC
dialogues.text: The revelries come to a halt as the door to the house swi open and Michael steps out.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Where on Earth have you all been? (To Mary Poppins: ) I told you to bring them straight home. I’ve been worried sick! The children stop in their tracks, startled. Behind them, the leeries except for Jack have mysteriously disappeared into the fog.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: We're sorry we're late, father. It wasn’t Mary Poppins’ fault.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We got lost in the fog.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Jack and the leeries led us down the ‘frog and toad.’

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: He means ‘road.’

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So you've been off filling the children’s heads with stuff and nonsense. I’ve heard quite enough - come in at once!  97

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Best I take my leave. Good night, Mary Poppins.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Good night, Jack. The children hurry inside, with Mary Poppins following th Michael enters last, shutting the door firmly behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen is waiting in the front entry hall as everyone ente

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Into the parlor - go on. The children obey.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Don't be too ‘ard on ‘em, Sir. They are just children, after all.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Turning back, testily:) Of course they’re children - my children - and I will deal with them as I see fit. Now leave us to it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. She heads into the kitchen. Mary Poppins starts upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Not you, Mary Poppins. In here.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Very well, sir. She follows Michael into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -.+. where the children await sentence. Michael takes a m to get control over his emotions before he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You could have lost me my job - do you understand that? A good position like mine is hard to come by these days. But there you all were, running about — (Turning to Mary Poppins: ) (more)  98 MICHAEL (cont'd) And I thought that you, Mary Poppins - I thought you were here to look after these children.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It wasn’t her doing, it was me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: It was us. We thought maybe if we talked to Mr. Frye, he could give you more time to save the house.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We were only trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well, you didn’t help! (A deep breath: ) I know this has been a difficult year for our family, and I have done my best to keep the three of you from worrying - but I can’t do this alone. It’s too much. I’m barely holding on as it is. I can’t even seem to remember my briefcase in the morning, and there is no more time, we're about to lose this house - and I can’t lose our home... I just don’t know what to do anymore, I don’t know what to do. Everything has fallen to pieces since your mother... (Suddenly overcome. ) Haven’t we lost enough already?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (After a beat.) We haven’t lost mother. Not really... “THE PLACE WHERE LOST THINGS GO” - reprise GEORGIE (cont'd) NOTHING’S GONE FOREVER ONLY OUT OF PLACE...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Deeply moved: ) When did you all get so clever?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Last night. Mary Poppins told us... Georgie is about to say more when Mary Poppins catches hi eye and raises a finger to her lips, mouthing a silent “S Michael kneels in front of the children.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I hope I am as clever as you when I grow up. You’re right. Your mother’s not gone. She’s in your smile, Georgie, and John’s walk, and Annabel’s eyes. And she’1ll always be with us wherever we go. Michael wraps them in his arms. Mary Poppins takes this i look of satisfaction in her eyes. MICHAEL (cont'd) Go on, now - time to wash your hands for dinner. The children go. Michael turns to Mary Poppins. MICHAEL (cont'd) Did you have something to do with them trying to save the house?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: I never said a word - it was all the children’s idea.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (After a pause.) The whole time I’ve been looking after them, they’ve been looking after me... (He shakes his head.) I had it all backwards.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Hmm. A Banks family trait.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What was I thinking?  100

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Some people think a great deal too much. Of that I am certain. She disappears upstairs, leaving Michael to ponder this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN MONTAGE - VARIOUS SHOTS of London at night - the sidew empty, the street lamps lit, and the fog rolling in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wind rustles the fallen leaves on Cherry Tree Lane, sendi them rustling down the cobblestones. At 17 Cherry Tree Lane, Jack, Angus, and two other leerie search through boxes in the back of a moving van filled w the family’s possessions. Aunt Jane comes out of the hous carrying a box. Jack hurries over to help Aunt Jane with

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Here, Jane - let me help you with that. He takes the box. Aunt Jane nods toward the van.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you. No luck?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Shaking his head: ) We can look through everything again if you like.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: There’s no point. It’s nearly midnight - we tried our best. Thank you, Jack. And thanks to your friends for helping us.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Of course. Anything for you. Aunt Jane smiles.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: We'll be out in a moment. She goes back into the house. Jack signals to Binnacle, w stands watching from the adjoining rooftop.  101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael stands in the entryway to the sitting room. The furniture is gone; the curtains have been taken down. Aun Jane comes in and crosses to Michael’s side. A pause as their situation sinks in. They look around the empty sitting room one last time. The children come downstairs with suitcases, followed by Poppins, carpetbag in hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: The children have packed up the last of their things themselves.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well done, all of you. (Putting an arm around Georgie: ) Have you got Gillie?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Yes, father. Ellen comes out of the kitchen with suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Good riddance to that old kitchen. Never could figure out that stove.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well, then... we’ve spent every last moment we can here. It’s time to say goodbye. (His voice echoing: ) Goodbye, old friend!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE AND THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Goodbye, old friend! Aunt Jane crosses to open the door and everyone files out Michael turns out the lights and shuts the door behind hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family steps outside, surprised to discover a handful neighbors and friends coming over from the Admiral’s hous Miss Lark and the Milkman are there, along with the Admir and Binnacle.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Knowing the answer: ) What are you all doing here so late?  102

dialogues.speaker: BINNACLE
dialogues.text: We've been waitin’ to see you off.

dialogues.speaker: MILKMAN
dialogues.text: We'd be here no matter what the hour.

dialogues.speaker: MISS LARK
dialogues.text: If you and your family should ever need a place to stay, Willoughby and I would be happy for the company.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Lark. Jane has offered to put us up in her flat, at least for the time being.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: For as long as you like. (To Ellen: ) I wish you’d come with us, Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Don’t you worry ‘bout me. I got a nice room fixed up at my sister’s.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: You won’t leave us, will you, Mary Poppins?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t be silly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: She says she’s not leaving until the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (He laughs, perplexed: ) In any case, your home is with us. (To Georgie, smiling: ) I’m pleased she got caught on your string, Georgie. Georgie hurries forward as Michael is about to lock the d

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: My kite - I forgot my kite!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Very well - but be quick about it. Georgie runs into the house. Binnacle pushes the Admiral’ wheelchair over to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: BINNACLE
dialogues.text: The Admiral has something he would like to give you, Mr. Banks, Sir.  103 The Admiral hands him a beautifully-wrought ship in a bot

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: The H.M.S. Glad Tidings - I commanded her myself. May she guide you safely into port.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you so much, Admiral. (He salutes: ) I’ll take good care of her. The Admiral checks his pocket watch.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: It’s nearly eight bells, Mr. Binnacle. Time to man our posts.

dialogues.speaker: BINNACLE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Goodbye, Mr. Banks, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr Binnacle. As Binnacle wheels the Admiral off, Georgie comes out of house, his arms wrapped around his kite.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I found it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m not so sure that will get off the ground anymore - it looks more glue than kite. Michael takes a few steps toward the house, then glances MICHAEL (cont'd) Georgie, did you patch that up with one of my old drawings? It looks like you've done a fine job, there. Michael gestures for Georgie to hand him the kite. He run hand over the patches that Georgie has made from his sket of Michael, Kate and the children. MICHAEL (cont'd) (kneels ) Look at that - all of us together in front of the... As he holds up the kite, light from the streetlamp hits i from behind. Printed lettering, upside down and backwards shows through the patches. Michael blinks. He turns the k over and pieces together the words written on the patches CERTIFICATE OF SHARES.  104

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: What is it, father?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Wait..! (Stunned and elated: ) “Certificate of Shares!” This is it - this is what we’ve been looking for! (Suddenly panicked: ) We have to get to the bank! What time is it - anyone??

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (Checking his watch: ) Seven minutes to midnight.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Seven minutes? It’s not enough. We need to make it to the bank by midnight.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Take the van.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No, it’s no good. You still won't make it in time.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: What can we do?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Defeated: ) Nothing. We can’t turn back time.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: (After a beat: ) Why not? “Everything is possible - even the impossible.” She looks to Mary Poppins. Mary Poppins smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Can we do it, then, Mary Poppins? Can we turn back time?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: I don’t see why that couldn’t be arranged.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: That’s ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Indeed it is, Michael. It’s nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Foolishness!  105

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It makes no sense! And if it makes no sense-

dialogues.speaker: JOHN/ANNABEL/ GEORGIE
dialogues.text: It can’t be true!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What are you all talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Never you mind. You just get to the bank as fast as possible with that kite, and leave the rest to us. Mary Poppins guides Michael and Aunt Jane over to the van they climb into the cab:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: But how will you - ?

dialogues.speaker: THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Go! Michael nods. He closes the door and they drive off. Mary Poppins turns to Jack. They walk to his bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: We'll need a lot of help, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Good as done! Angus, gather the leeries!

dialogues.speaker: ANGUS
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Children, help me ready the bicycle! Angus and the leeries run to their bicycles. Georgie and twins hurry to Jack’s bicycle, flipping the ladder sidewa across the rear fender. Mary Poppins hikes her skirts and climbs onto the bicycle seat sidesaddle.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: I'll take the reins this time - speed is of the essence.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Have you ever ridden a bicycle like this before?

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: (An impatient sigh: ) Oh, please - how different can it be from riding an elephant? (more)  106 MARY POPPINS (cont'd) Climb aboard everyone. Ready, and... up! Now all we have to do is turn back time. The bicycle rockets down the lane, Mary Poppins leading t leeries, not bothering - and somehow not needing - to ped

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH ANGLE as Mary Poppins, Jack and the children race do the Mall with Angus and the other two leeries behind them each turn, more leeries appear, swerving bicycles around corners, squeezing through hedges and leaping curbs to jo the pack. INT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - NIGHT/CONTINUOUS Wilkins, meanwhile, is in his office with Gooding and Fry Big Ben can be seen through the window behind them.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: A good week’s work, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Thank you sir.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: (Pulls out his pocket watch, checks the time.) Looks as if Banks won't be joining us tonight.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: He does have a few more minutes. You said you’d wait until the last stroke of midnight.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Of course. I know that. So we'll wait - I’m aman of my word. Wilkins unwraps a toffee and pops it into his mouth, hand the empty wrapper to Gooding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More Leeries join as the bicycles race toward Big Ben.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. RESIDENTIAL STREET/VAN
dialogues.text: Michael and Aunt Jane drive fast through the quiet street

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: How much time do we have?  107

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: There’s only five minutes left, I think!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty leeries, Mary Poppins and the twins stand on the rooftop of Parliament next to Big Ben. Angus helps Georgi climb up the last few rungs of a ladder, Jack right behin John gestures to one of the Leeries for his cap.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Hushed urgency: ) Good - now over to the tower! The leeries all grab ladders and rush to the tower. John, head down in his Leerie cap, lifts a ladder and starts to follow them. JACK (cont'd) Sorry - this is as far as you go. (Taking the ladder: ) Back in a flash. Jack hurries to the tower throwing his ladder to Angus. JACK (cont'd) C’mon. Jack runs up to the wall and begins to climb. Angus split the ladder and throws up the top half to jack. Jack jams the ladder diagonally against the wall. Angus throws up another ladder is passed up to him. He places t on the opposite diagonal to the first, and start to climb the ladder as Angus starts to climb below him. The others put their ladders against the wall and climb u behind him, passing ladders overhead. It is a hair-raisingly dangerous process that looks almos certain to end in disaster. Mary Poppins and the children watch from THE ROOFTOP as J climbs up to a ledge. A pigeon suddenly rushes out at him making him drop his ladder. He loses his balance and hang from the ledge.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: I can’t watch! Mary Poppins shakes her head in disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: You would think they’d never done this before.  108 BACK ON THE TOWER, Jack climbs into an arch, having nearl reached the clock’s face. He looks up, realizing the over prevents them from reaching it.

dialogues.speaker: ANGUS
dialogues.text: (Calls up to him:) What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (Shouting down: ) I've got an idea! C’mon! Jack jumps into the arch. Angus climbs up onto the ledge outside the arch. Jack calls down to the Leeries below. JACK (cont'd) Ladder! Another Leerie climbs up, a second passes up two ladders, jumping up behind him. They interlock the ladders. Jack places it out over the e like a diving board. He walks out onto the end of the ladder, as two Leeries h it steady from inside the arch. Jack turns round at the very edge, a huge drop below him. steadies himself. ON THE ROOFTOP - the children gasp as they watch Jack fly into the air, backlit by the glowing face of Big Ben’s di AT THE TOWER - Jack lands on the ledge beneath the clock’ face. He opens a small hinged window set into the face of clock and squeezes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack squints around the tower, finding the gas main. He cranks it closed, shutting off the gaslights that illumin all the faces of the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children watch as Big Ben goes dark. Jack sticks his head out of the open window. Angus calls to him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGUS
dialogues.text: You can turn the time back now! Jack peers up at the enormous face of the clock.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How? I can’t reach the hands.  109 Down below, Mary Poppins sighs, growing exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Ohhh - ! Honestly!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: They’d better hurry. We have less than a minute to go. Up on the tower, the leeries seem to have run out of idea

dialogues.speaker: ANGUS
dialogues.text: We’re too late, Jack!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: There’s got to be a way!

dialogues.speaker: LOOK
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Mary Poppins appears, floating before the clock face, holding her umbrella. As she descends, she pushes t minute hand backward five and a half minutes. The leeries cheer. INT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - NIGHT Wilkins sits at his desk, flanked by Gooding and Frye, ey his pocket watch.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Three, two, one and... (Pause. ) Why hasn't Big Ben chimed?

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: Perhaps your watch is running fast.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Don’t be a simpleton - my watch has never run fast. Wilkins rises from his desk, pushing Frye out of the way, turns toward the window. The clock face on Big Ben is dar WILKINS (cont'd) What’s happened? Big Ben’s gone dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Poppins calls down to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: MARY POPPINS
dialogues.text: Relight the clock, Jack - quickly!  110 Jack rushes back inside to relight the clock. INT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - NIGHT Wilkins paces in frustration. Suddenly, the clock face on Ben relights in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Look! They've relit Big Ben.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: But that time is wrong - the clock must have stopped. Wilkins glances out the window to the street below, notic a van pulling up. He sees Michael getting out. WILKINS (cont'd) That’s Banks!

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: (Excited: ) He’s made it in time!

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Not yet he hasn’t! Go down there and see that he doesn’t get inside until that blasted clock strikes twelve.

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: But, sir -

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Now, Mr. Frye!

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. THE FRONT DOOR OF THE BANK
dialogues.text: On the street down below, Michael grabs the kite from the van. Michael and Aunt Jane hurry over to the bank. Just as Michael starts to open the door, though... Gooding and Frye rush through the lobby and grab the door handles from the INSIDE.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: Lock it, Mr Frye. OUTSIDE, Michael thinks the door is locked. He knocks.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL/AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Hello! Let us in please! We need to get in!  111

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Somebody let us in, please. Hello - is anyone there? INSIDE, Frye grows increasingly distraught. OUTSIDE, Michael glances at the kite in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Jane - let’s go fly a kite! Michael and Aunt Jane run back round the side of the bank desperately try to fly the kite up to Wilkins office. MICHAEL (cont'd) (Points at the window: ) There it is! It’s the one with the light.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Is he there?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I think so, the light’s on.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Ok, here - let me hold it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I‘1l unspool it. You run. Go on -

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: One, two, three...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Go! INT/EXT. WILKINS’ OFFICE/BANK DOORS - CONTINUOUS/INTERCUT As Wilkins settles into his office chair, the kite flies view outside the window behind him. DOWN BELOW, Michael and Aunt Jane are flying the kite, tr to position it outside the balcony so Wilkins will see it

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: It won’t work - He’s never going to see it! As BIG BEN BEGINS TO TOLL MIDNIGHT, Mary Poppins appears the sky behind Michael and Aunt Jane, umbrella in hand. S takes a breath and gently blows. The wind rises, the wind fly open and the kite breaks free from its string... «+. floating into WILKINS’ OFFICE. It hits Wilkins in the back of the head, before landing on his desk.  112 DOWN BELOW - Michael and Aunt Jane rush back to pull on t bank doors. INSIDE, Gooding continues to resist - but Frye can’t take anymore. He lets go of the handle and steps back. Gooding goes sprawling as the door swings open and Michael and Au Jane rush inside, thinking the men have unlocked the door

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh - thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: Hurry, Mr. Banks! Frye catches Gooding glaring at him.

dialogues.speaker: GOODING
dialogues.text: What! In the OFFICE, Wilkins stares at the kite on his desk, bewildered. He sees the words “Certificate of Shares” pee through a hole in the kite.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: What is this? Michael bursts through the open door just as Big Ben chim its final note.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s what we’ve been looking for. EXT. CHERRY TREE LANE, THE ADMIRAL’S ROOFTOP - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL BOOM
dialogues.text: Three, two, one... FIRE! Binnacle fires the cannon - BOOM! The Admiral nods, impre ADMIRAL BOOM (cont'd) Mr. Binnacle - Big Ben has finally got it right. INT. WILKINS’ OFFICE - A FEW MINUTES LATER Michael gently peels a piece of the share certificate off kite. Wilkins, Aunt Jane, Mary Poppins, Jack, the childre and the lawyers watch as he places it with the rest of th share certificate, which lies on the desk - in fragments, nearly complete.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: And this one goes here...  113

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: Does it matter if it’s all cut up in bits? Is it still worth anything?

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: It’s valid so long as all the pieces are there.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: (Through gritted teeth: ) Is that so? Michael examines the kite, searching for the final piece. It’s not there.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Georgie, there was one more piece - a corner piece with a lot of signatures. Do you remember it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: I must have thrown it out. I’m sorry, father.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s alright, Georgie -

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: No, it isn’t. I’m afraid you have a problem, Banks. Without those signatures, you have no bank shares, no house - you have nothing. Michael turns, looking at Wilkins with new eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: But he knows you have bank shares!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: He’s been planning this all along!

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Take your children out of here, Banks. I’ve heard enough of their lies.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Eyes blazing with anger: ) Don’t you dare insult my children - don’t you DARE! They’re not lying and you know it. I only wish I had believed them sooner. (Turning to his children: ) (more)  114 MICHAEL (cont'd) You all had him pegged right from the start. (To Wilkins: ) Take the house - go ahead. (Putting his arms around the children: ) I have everything I need right here. A double door that leads into an adjacent boardroom swing open. MR. DAWES, JR. enters (80s - full of vigor). MR. DAWES, JR. He has you there, Willie.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Uncle Dawes?? What on earth are you doing here? MR. DAWES, JR. A little bird told me that you’ve been trying to cheat the Banks family out of their shares in Fidelity Fiduciary.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That he has, we heard him. Dawes glances over to Mary Poppins’ parrot umbrella. The umbrella gives him a sly wink. MR. DAWES, JR. I also hear you've been telling the whole of London I’ve gone loony. The only loony thing I did is trust you to look after this bank.

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: You can’t be serious! I’ve nearly doubled the profits of this bank. MR. DAWES, JR. Yes, by wringing it out of our customer's pockets. Their trust in us built this bank - and now you've squandered every last bit of their good will. So I’m back, and you're out. (To Gooding and Frye:) See my nephew to the door, would you, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: FRYE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, Mr. Dawes. The lawyers take Wilkins by an arm, leading him to the do  115

dialogues.speaker: WILKINS
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me - (Shrugs them off:) You’re not fit to run this bank! They are gone. MR. DAWES, JR. We'll see about that. I may be circling the drain, but I still have a few steps left in me. Mr. Dawes, Jr. kicks up his heels in a little SONG AND DA “TRIP A LITTLE LIGHT FANTASTIC” - reprise MR. DAWES, JR. (cont'd) SO... WHEN... THEY...

dialogues.speaker: AND YOUR CHANCE TO DANCE IS DONE
dialogues.text: THAT’S THE TIME TO STAND

dialogues.speaker: TO STRIKE UP THE BAND
dialogues.text: AND TELL ‘EM THAT YOU'VE JUST

dialogues.speaker: BEGUN
dialogues.text: SO WHEN LIFE’S A REAL PEA-SOUPER

dialogues.speaker: AS YOU...
dialogues.text: Mr. Dawes, Jr. dances onto the top of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: WITH ME
dialogues.text: +. Dawes hops off the desk and sits in his old chair as t children skip round him.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAWES, JR.
dialogues.text: (Gesturing to his legs) Children, help me with my legs. The children help lift Mr. Dawes’s leg off the table.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So glad to have you back, Mr. Dawes.  116 MR. DAWES, JR. Thank you, Michael. And by the way - those shares of yours are perfectly fine - save them for your family.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I don’t understand - MR. DAWES, JR. I'd like to tell you a little story. They gather beside him. As “FEED THE BIRDS” plays under: MR. DAWES, JR. (cont'd) Once upon a time there was a man with a wooden leg named Smith - Oh no, no, no. Not that one. There was little boy named Michael who wanted to give his tuppence to a bird lady - but in the end, and after a little persuasion, he decided to give it to his father instead. Michael’s father - your grandfather - gave that tuppence to this bank and he asked us to guard it well. We did just that, and thanks to several quite clever investments - if I do say so myself... (Turning to Michael: ) That tuppence has grown into quite a sum!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Really? MR. DAWES, JR. (With a smile:) Really, Michael. Enough, in fact, to pay off that loan you took. The house is yours. The Banks children rush to hug their father. Mary Poppins off to the side, allows herself a little satisfied grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NEXT MORNING - Spring has arrived on swift wings. Che trees rustle in the breeze, heavy with new blossoms. Mary Poppins, Ellen and the family walk down the lane to the B home.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What a beautiful day to be going back home again.  117

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Look at these lovely cherry blossoms!

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes, they are. I’1ll have to paint them. What about you, Jane?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (Jumping in:) He means what about you and that handsome lamplighter, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: No, no, no - we’re just friends. Really.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (Tongue in cheek: ) Mmm-hmm... go on.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (Looking ahead: ) What’s this? Through the park gates, they see that colorful tents have been set up in the center of the green. Crowds stand in l for food carts, games of chance, and a small Ferris wheel

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: The Spring Fair - it’s today! Can we go?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Please?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t see why not.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Hooray! The children surround their father, urging him along with them as they rush into the park.

dialogues.speaker: ANNABEL
dialogues.text: Come on, Father - let’s go!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Will you go on the Ferris wheel with us?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes, yes - and you too, Jane!  118

dialogues.speaker: AUNT JANE
dialogues.text: (Taking Ellen’s arm:) Only if Ellen comes with me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t be caught dead on that thing... The family hurries ahead, as their voices trail off. Mary Poppins slows, a knowing look in her eyes as she watches go on ahead without her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family arrives at the fair. There are familiar faces the crowd: Miss Lark and Willoughby, the Milkman - even t Park Keeper, having a miserable time watching everyone trample over his grass. A street organ begins to play. CLOSE on a bundle of balloons. WE CIRCLE ROUND to reveal BALLOON LADY - a kind-hearted street vendor who is perhap little bit magical. “NOWHERE TO GO BUT UP”

dialogues.speaker: BALLOON LADY
dialogues.text: LIFE’S A BALLOON

dialogues.speaker: AND OH, DEARIE DUCKS
dialogues.text: THEN YOU’RE IN FOR A RIDE...

dialogues.speaker: AND IF YOU HEAR A TUNE
dialogues.text: THERE’S NOWHERE TO GO BUT UP Georgie sees a bundle of balloons across the fairgrounds.
